Heya,

Just wondering, should nested virtualization into consideration here ? where you can expose hardware extensions (e.g./dev/kvm character device) /inside/ the L1 guest.

[Terminology: L0 - Physical Host ; L1 - Guest hypervisor; L2 - Nested guest (running on L1) ]

Or would that be overkill for the scope of this fix ?'}, {'account_id': 7677, 'date': '2013-05-31 14:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7677, 'date': '2013-05-31 14:28:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Revision 2 just added a bit of caching so as not to query /proc/cpuinfo if we have already queried it before

@Kashyap: I think that may be a bit of overkill for the scope of this patch, but I could take a shot at it.  Is there a better way to detect KVM nested support than something like `cat /proc/modules | grep 'kvm.*nested'` (or the equivalent python)?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-31 14:59:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 21:49:43.000000000', 'message': 'Provides an auto option to auto-detect if we are running on a hypervisor, and in turn set libvirt_type appropriately

Users can now set libvirt_type to auto (which is now the default)
which will use /proc/cpuinfo to detect if they are running on
a hypervisor at run time, and return the correct libvirt_type
value (i.e. kvm if not on a hypervisor, qemu if on a hypervisor).
Additionally, users may specify auto-* (where * is a valid value
for libvirt_type) to use * instead of kvm as the virtualization
type when not on a hypervisor.

Implements: hypervisor autodetection
Fixes: bug #1100366
Change-Id: I57d60c02afdd30557ddd3dd773886de8cbd2efbc
'}, {'created': '2013-05-31 14:14:32.000000000', 'message': 'Provides an auto option to auto-detect if we are running on a hypervisor, and in turn set libvirt_type appropriately

Users can now set libvirt_type to auto (which is now the default)
which will use /proc/cpuinfo to detect if they are running on
a hypervisor at run time, and return the correct libvirt_type
value (i.e. kvm if not on a hypervisor, qemu if on a hypervisor).
Additionally, users may specify auto-* (where * is a valid value
for libvirt_type) to use * instead of kvm as the virtualization
type when not on a hypervisor.  Caches the result of the
/proc/cpuinfo so as not to require a read of /proc/cpuinfo
every time the option is accessed.

'}, {'created': '2013-06-24 20:03:54.000000000', 'message': 'Autodetect hypervisor presence to set libvirt_type

Users can now set libvirt_type to auto (which is now the default)
which will use the built-in libvirt auto-detection to detect
a hypervisor at run time.  This value is then retrieved from
libvirt and cached for future use, and is accessible via
hypervisor_type (which will use libvirt_type if it is explicitly
set).  In case a libvirt connection is not readily available
and a hypervisor type is not passed to us (as in the case of
some of the util functions in the virt/libvirt directory),
a connection is made for the purposes of determining the hypervisor type,
and is subsequently closed.  All applicable calls to CONF.libvirt_type
have been replaced with driver.hypervisor_type (or the like,
as explained above).

Implements: hypervisor autodetection
Fixes: bug #1100366
Change-Id: I57d60c02afdd30557ddd3dd773886de8cbd2efbc
'}]
commit_message:
Autodetect hypervisor presence to set libvirt_type

Users can now set libvirt_type to auto (which is now the default)
which will use the built-in libvirt auto-detection to detect
a hypervisor at run time.  This value is then retrieved from
libvirt and cached for future use, and is accessible via
hypervisor_type (which will use libvirt_type if it is explicitly
set).  In case a libvirt connection is not readily available
and a hypervisor type is not passed to us (as in the case of
some of the util functions in the virt/libvirt directory),
a connection is made for the purposes of determining the hypervisor type,
and is subsequently closed.  All applicable calls to CONF.libvirt_type
have been replaced with driver.hypervisor_type (or the like,
as explained above).

Implements: hypervisor autodetection
Fixes: bug #1100366
Change-Id: I57d60c02afdd30557ddd3dd773886de8cbd2efbc

commit_message:
Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730
Change-Id: Ic2be96e9f03d2ca46d060caf6f6f7f713a1d6b82

commit_message:
Base validation framework implemented

* validate(schema, *validators) - method validates request body using the
  specified jsonschema and then validate request body using validators
  (callables);

* check_exists(get_func, *id_prop, **get_args) - method checks that object
  is available using specifed function and magic props for defining id-arg
  mapping for calling function;

* ApiValidator added w/ support of uuid type;

* unit tests for ApiValidator has been added.

Partially implements blueprint savanna-rest-api-1-0-validation

Change-Id: Ieb2b9c46ab58e7ec4900016f21164d07bcfba30d

commit_message:
cinder.[brick,db,image] Replace 'locals()'

        Replace use of 'locals()' with explicit values.
        Help bring source code into compliance with the
        Cinder Style Commandments:
        https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/HACKING.rst

        This change covers all affected soruce in the
        cinder brick, db, and image modules, i.e.
        cinder/brick/*.py and subdirectories
        cinder/db/*.py and subdirectories
        cinder/image/*.py and subdirectories

        Partially fixes: bug #1190758

Change-Id: Ibc111ab5ef53a2316e868c9cba8b94b323ba31c0

subject: Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.openstack.*
messages:
[{'account_id': 7740, 'date': '2013-06-25 16:49:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

It's my understanding that code in openstack-common should be modified only in the upstream oslo repository.  From the README in cinder/openstack/common:

openstack-common
----------------

A number of modules from openstack-common are imported into this project.

These modules are "incubating" in openstack-common and are kept in sync
with the help of openstack-common's update.py script. See:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonLibrary#Incubation

The copy of the code should never be directly modified here. Please
always update openstack-common first and then run the script to copy
the changes across.'}, {'account_id': 7593, 'date': '2013-06-25 16:51:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Agree with Andrew Forrest'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 16:37:12.000000000', 'message': 'Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.openstack.*

Using of locals() for formatting string is a nasty thing because:
1) It is not so clear as using explicit dicts
2) It could produce hidden errors during refactoring
3) Changing name of variable causes change in message
4) Creating a lot of unused variables

Fix bug 1171936

Change-Id: I828b21e3bdbf315bd89858d6a23e9a6e8160d809
'}]
commit_message:
Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.openstack.*

Using of locals() for formatting string is a nasty thing because:
1) It is not so clear as using explicit dicts
2) It could produce hidden errors during refactoring
3) Changing name of variable causes change in message
4) Creating a lot of unused variables

Fix bug 1171936

Change-Id: I828b21e3bdbf315bd89858d6a23e9a6e8160d809

commit_message:
Connectivity between the endpoint version and OS_VOLUME_API_VERSION.

Adds functionality which allows user to work with
that cinder API version which is the same as
the endpoint version.

Fixes: bug #1169455

Change-Id: I9bb46e602d15856d2da502a6ac2b6c25e76f4fa3

'}, {'account_id': 7494, 'date': '2013-06-24 11:58:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Thanks John!'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-24 18:20:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-24 18:24:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 27: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(3 inline comments)

A couple of inline questions.

Also, I'm struggling to understand where the line is going to be drawn between the conductor and scheduler.  It looks like the scheduler will be called to select a host but then there are additional checks that might filter out a host.  I see

    self._check_destination_is_not_source()
    self._check_host_is_up(self.destination)
    self._check_destination_has_enough_memory()
    self._check_compatible_with_source_hypervisor(self.destination)
    self._call_livem_checks_on_host(self.destination)

and it seems like everything but _call_livem_checks_on_host() and perhaps _check_compatible_with_source_hypervisor might be things the scheduler can handle.  I know this is basically a copy out of scheduler/driver.py so I don't expect this to change here.  Just kind of curious what the plan is moving forward?"}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-25 09:15:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: (5 inline comments)

So my plan was that select hosts is the only call to the scheduler for select hosts, and keep all the calls to the compute nodes to happen from the conductor.

I get your point though, those pre-checks could be considered scheduler work. I just want to keep the scheduler as simple as possible, and keep all the live-migrate related complexity in one place. Also, makes the case when the user requests a host more similar to the scheduled case.

Anyway, I am sure we can evolve the contract between the scheduler and conductor over time. I just went for the simplest possible, so that is more likely to be common with resize / migrate.

There is also some complexity around info from those check calls need to be passed back into the live_migrate call. (in XenAPI its a dict that contains the information for the two XenServers to communicate between each other correctly)'}, {'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-25 15:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

(2 inline comments)

Thanks for the information John.  I definitely agree with keeping patchsets as small as reasonably possible and holding off on certain changes until later.  Just wanted to understand the direction this is headed since only one more patch is up right now(plus a WIP).'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-25 15:23:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 27: No score

Starting gate jobs.

commit_message:
Extract live-migration scheduler logic from the scheduler driver

Before moving the control of live-migration into the conductor,
extract the live-migration control logic into a separate class.

The callback to select_hosts will be replaced by a new
scheduler rpc method in a later changeset.

Part of blueprint live-migration-to-conductor
Change-Id: I6de33ada6dc377e20f8df07da92244f2c150b9fe

commit_message:
OS::Quantum::Subnet resource, add enable_dhcp

Add enable_dhcp to the properties schema, since quantumclient
code indicates this is allowed in the body (not only expected
in the response as currently indicated by the docs)

Fixes bug #1194394

Change-Id: I19770b033696ea9a27b6e985a52bf2cfadb16f52

commit_message:
cinder.[brick,db,image] Replace 'locals()'

    Replace use of 'locals()' with explicit values.
    Help bring source code into compliance with the
    Cinder Style Commandments:
    https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/HACKING.rst

    This change covers all affected soruce in the
    cinder brick, db, and image modules, i.e.
    cinder/brick/*.py and subdirectories
    cinder/db/*.py and subdirectories
    cinder/image/*.py and subdirectories

    Partially fixes: bug #1190758

    Change-Id: I83b8af04fb8861212da573a617a1fc48b936297c

Change-Id: Ic7d42aeae67821097ef9a88e70f4bdeda7b9804d

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 15:54:13.000000000', 'message': 'Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730

commit_message:
Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730

Change-Id: Id4aaadde7e69f0bc087cf6d96bb041d53feb131d

commit_message:
Configurable volume storage_protocol + vendor_name

Allow storage_protocol and vendor name of configured backend
to be set in tempest.conf, allowing volume tests against drivers
other than the default (iSCSI).

Fixes bug #1194316

Change-Id: Ifd879d16e021b99e3d3d221e0bfea2f35e1a9767

subject: IPMI ensures node power off before powering on.
messages:
[{'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-05-28 01:41:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It looks good to me. Two things I think need considering:
 - tests
 - what's the interaction with 'nova stop' and 'nova start' - does 'nova start' call the activate_node() code path? If so this seems wrong for that."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-05-28 01:42:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Oh - that should be power off hard, *not* power off.

power off won't override the OS if the OS decides to not power down, AFAICT."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-28 02:24:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30650/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/27002 : SUCCESS in 3m 03s

- http://logs.openstack.org/30650/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/12376 : SUCCESS in 9m 13s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-05-28 15:45:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@lifeless:

Yes, "nova stop" & "nova start" call down to [de]activate_node. I don't see a problem with that. Could you clarify why you do?

(re states.DELETED, I have filed https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1185081 to rename the state)

As far as "power off hard", my read of the ipmitool man page differs from what you're suggesting.

  
  http://linux.die.net/man/1/ipmitool
  
  off
  Power down chassis into soft off (S4/S5 state). WARNING: This command does not initiate a clean shutdown of the operating system prior to powering down the system.
  
  soft
  Initiate a soft-shutdown of OS via ACPI. This can be done in a number of ways, commonly by simulating an overtemperture or by simulating a power button press. It is necessary for there to be Operating System support for ACPI and some sort of daemon watching for events for this soft power to work'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:00:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'd also like to see a test."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-08 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Having 'nova start' cause a power cycle on an already running machine seems like a very suprising thing.

# As far as "power off hard", my read of the ipmitool man page differs from what you're suggesting.

Yeah well. Man pages huh. So, when I was debugging our test rack, I'm pretty sure I saw ACPI shutdown happen in response to power off

However, lets not block on that - we can see what happens and iterate. The impact on 'nova start' is my one remaining concern.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2013-06-14 18:10:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
IPMI ensures node power off before powering on.

Baremetal IPMI driver will ensure that node power is OFF
before trying to turn it ON. This fixes bug 1178919, which resulted
from trying to turn on nodes that were already on, and then waiting
indefinitely for a DHCP BOOT request that never arrived.

Change-Id: I3e0418037d14617e68954da6c7b341fef3a12a3b

Change-Id: I94c23973bdad603703f12e936b7e72fe0e81c3f0
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes crash when no help for an option

When there is no help available for an option, the generator.py
simply crashes. This fixes this by initialising opt_help.

Fixes Bug1194524

Change-Id: I94c23973bdad603703f12e936b7e72fe0e81c3f0

commit_message:

* return None instead of NoneType error doesn't containt some property

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 10:42:41.000000000', 'message': 'Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730

Change-Id: I7bce659591c4c3e4bc41e12d7d8390128c30e2e4
'}, {'created': '2013-06-25 10:55:20.000000000', 'message': 'Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730

Change-Id: I7bce659591c4c3e4bc41e12d7d8390128c30e2e4
'}]
commit_message:
Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730

Change-Id: I7bce659591c4c3e4bc41e12d7d8390128c30e2e4

Change-Id: I084057810fc4fb7fdac05494cc6fec2cbf81bb9d
'}]
commit_message:
Use object name from request in bulk Errors

This will allow users to more easily match the failed objects in Errors
for bulk delete requests to the object names they provided in the request.
For extract Errors, it reports the failed path from the tar archive.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I084057810fc4fb7fdac05494cc6fec2cbf81bb9d

commit_message:
Replace nosetests with testr in tox.ini.

Config tox.ini updated to run testr instead of nosetests.
File test-requirements.txt modified respectively.
Config .testr.conf added.

Testr allows for more flexible testing, more consistent use of the
unittest protocol and, most importantly, faster testing via parallelism.

Part of blueprint run-tests-script.

Change-Id: Iba847d430a18458a1a68e6ef07541d29c0c01c64

commit_message:
Port quota API into v3 part2

This patch contains the changes required to adapt the service
extension and the corresponding unittest to the v3 framework

And also doing some change as below:
* Currently update quota with value < -1 will raise HTTPBadRequest, but update with
non-integer won't. Make both of them raise HTTPBadRequest for consistent.
* Modify the response of update quota include 'id' that is same with show quota.
* Merge extended_quotas into quota_sets
* Use policy checking instead of nova.context.authorize_project_context
* Cleanup

Partially implements bp v3-api-extension-versioning

Change-Id: I44840d7e86b14832ece613220ff0850c801cffa9

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-19 06:19:50.000000000', 'message': "Remove the unused plugins framework

This framework was merged a year ago and AFAICT hasn't seen use beyond
the two initial wikimedia extensions for Nova.

The framework basically allows a way for a single plugin to register API
extensions and notification hooks. Both of these can be done by directly
using config opts like osapi_compute_extension and notification_driver
so this framework really only helps if we expected to (and wanted to)
lots of these plugins in the wild.

Nova is the only project using this and we don't have an active
maintainer listed in the MAINTAINERS file, so it seems like it's time to
remove it from the incubator.

Change-Id: I5552b5625e26f4821464807743545ec6f5117f2b
"}, {'created': '2013-06-19 07:48:34.000000000', 'message': "Remove the unused plugins framework

commit_message:
Remove the unused plugins framework

This framework was merged a year ago and AFAICT hasn't seen use beyond
the two initial wikimedia extensions for Nova.

The framework basically allows a way for a single plugin to register API
extensions and notification hooks. Both of these can be done by directly
using config opts like osapi_compute_extension and notification_driver
so this framework really only helps if we expected to (and wanted to)
lots of these plugins in the wild.

Nova is the only project using this and we don't have an active
maintainer listed in the MAINTAINERS file, so it seems like it's time to
remove it from the incubator.

Change-Id: I5552b5625e26f4821464807743545ec6f5117f2b

[{'created': '2013-06-10 14:15:46.000000000', 'message': "Allow BaseTestCase use a different conf object

The new messaging work will register options like rpc_backend and, since
the existing RPC API registers those options with CONF, we need to run
the messaging tests with a different ConfigOpts object.

It's actually probably pretty sane for all unit tests to use a per-test
ConfigOpts object rather than cfg.CONF anyway.

The kombu and zmq tests have an issue with this where they rely on being
able to call self.config() before the base class setUp() is called.

Change-Id: I7b2e3db7c21c511f3ab16ac866e0cc80846cbd80

commit_message:
Allow BaseTestCase use a different conf object

The new messaging work will register options like rpc_backend and, since
the existing RPC API registers those options with CONF, we need to run
the messaging tests with a different ConfigOpts object.

It's actually probably pretty sane for all unit tests to use a per-test
ConfigOpts object rather than cfg.CONF anyway.

The kombu and zmq tests have an issue with this where they rely on being
able to call self.config() before the base class setUp() is called.
Fixing this properly is a little tricky, so for now, initialize
self.conf early to cfg.CONF just for these tests.

Change-Id: I7b2e3db7c21c511f3ab16ac866e0cc80846cbd80

commit_message:
cinder.[brick,db,image] Replace 'locals()'

    Replace instances of 'locals()' with explicit values
    Help bring source code into compliance with the Cinder Style
    Commandments:
    https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/HACKING.rst

    This change covers all affected source in the cinder brick, db, and
    image modules. i.e.
    cinder/brick/*.py and subdirectories.
    cinder/db/*.py and subdirectories.
    cinder/image/*.py and subdirectories.

    Partially fixes: bug #1190748

Change-Id: Ie6293b0aba666249807624fd97673369a9e96b0e

commit_message:
cinder.[brick,db,image] Replace 'locals()'

    Replace use of 'locals()' with explicit values.
    Help bring source code into compliance with the
    Cinder Style Commandments:
    https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/HACKING.rst

    This change covers all affected soruce in the
    cinder brick, db, and image modules, i.e.
    cinder/brick/*.py and subdirectories
    cinder/db/*.py and subdirectories
    cinder/image/*.py and subdirectories

    Partially fixes: bug #1190758

    Change-Id: I83b8af04fb8861212da573a617a1fc48b936297c

Change-Id: Idd555ab08c353829744950b054b6ac38bf4abebe

Do not install percona-toolkit on Fedora.

percona-toolkit is not supported on Fedora.

commit_message:
Implement _map_to_user_inputs helper

It converts plain configs to the list of UserInput objects

* simple unit tests added
* __eq__ implemented for UserInput

Implements blueprint convert-user-input

Change-Id: I12c21ecf8b5ff8c8c4e4e6f01e1fc28118da0ab5

commit_message:
Added Cinder volume backup to Ceph support

Added new Ceph backup service to allow backup
of Cinder volumes to a Ceph object store. This
driver is compatible with the existing backup
interface provided by the Swift backup service.

Also added backup and restore to RBD driver.

Change-Id: Id0931e308fd3c15ec3901e8e666c19decec09b41
Implements: blueprint cinder-backup-to-ceph

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-24 18:27:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix auth logic for PUT /v2/alarms

The existing auth logic breaks threshold evaluation in a couple
of ways:

* arbitrary alarms are visible to the administrative ceilometer
  user, but state transformations cannot be recorded unless the
  alarm is actually owned by this user also

* using the passed X-User-Id header to set the user ID on the
  updated alarm would cause ownership of all alarms to be eventually
  assumed by the ceilometer user (once a state transformation
  occurs)

Change-Id: I0fcef188741c59fe2691e2009c28182dab51eb0b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix auth logic for PUT /v2/alarms

The existing auth logic breaks threshold evaluation in a couple
of ways:

* arbitrary alarms are visible to the administrative ceilometer
  user, but state transformations cannot be recorded unless the
  alarm is actually owned by this user also

* using the passed X-User-Id header to set the user ID on the
  updated alarm would cause ownership of all alarms to be eventually
  assumed by the ceilometer user (once a state transformation
  occurs)

Change-Id: I0fcef188741c59fe2691e2009c28182dab51eb0b

[{'created': '2013-06-24 18:43:12.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid unnecessary GET of existing alarm for update

The existing alarm representation is retrieved prior to update,
which is uneccessary as the API merges the new and existing
state in any case.

This change saves the threshold eval logic one unnecessary API
call per state transition.

Change-Id: If21c53d6f43164315e1e70e62b0c70520fb5a45c
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid unnecessary GET of existing alarm for update

The existing alarm representation is retrieved prior to update,
which is uneccessary as the API merges the new and existing
state in any case.

This change saves the threshold eval logic one unnecessary API
call per state transition.

Change-Id: If21c53d6f43164315e1e70e62b0c70520fb5a45c

commit_message:
Plugins could return required image tags now

* detailed plugin info (/plugins/plugin_name/hadoop_version) contains
  list of required image tags
* by default, required image tags: 'plugin_name', 'hadoop_version'

Partially implements blueprint filter-images-by-tag

Change-Id: I9f673f1496d7ef077c04c57ffefb88226854f0c1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 20:17:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for Rabbit Clustering using a single IP address.

Previsouly, you could only cluster Rabbit Brokers
if you specified multiple rabbit_hosts.

This patch removes the requirement to have multiple Rabbit host addresses.
You can now front-end the Rabbit Brokers using a load-balancer to
use Rabbit Mirrored Queues (rabbit_ha_queues).

OpenStack services will connect to a single, Virtual IP address
for high-availability and scalability purposes.

Defaults to false for backwards compatability and to not
implement rabbit_ha_queues.

Change-Id: Ibb1f0082f8c0dce85e75248bead582b8988d113b
'}]
commit_message:
Add support for Rabbit Clustering using a single IP address.

Previsouly, you could only cluster Rabbit Brokers
if you specified multiple rabbit_hosts.

This patch removes the requirement to have multiple Rabbit host addresses.
You can now front-end the Rabbit Brokers using a load-balancer to
use Rabbit Mirrored Queues (rabbit_ha_queues).

OpenStack services will connect to a single, Virtual IP address
for high-availability and scalability purposes.

Defaults to false for backwards compatability and to not
implement rabbit_ha_queues.

Change-Id: Ibb1f0082f8c0dce85e75248bead582b8988d113b

commit_message:
Allow blank keystone flavor in glance configs

Blank keystone flavor now allowed in api.pp and registry.pp
Pipeline config logically separate from keystone config (pipeline can
be set even if auth_type is not defined.)
Added rspec tests.

Change-Id: Ic4fbff44242459f504cd14ef18915b2efac2d032
Fixes: bug #1190475

Quantum does not include the tenant_id in port objects for floating IP addresses.
However, the Big Switch backend requires the tenant_id in the port removal requests.
This looks up the correct tenant_id whenever it is missing in the port removal.

Change-Id: I7580ed2f545ad2d92b831b65dfbb34541bf465aa
Fixes: bug #1190020
(cherry picked from commit f392263ae8c89412ec8be6a13b3dd56abd129a8c)

commit_message:
Always include tenant_id in port delete request

Quantum does not include the tenant_id in port objects for floating IP addresses.
However, the Big Switch backend requires the tenant_id in the port removal requests.
This looks up the correct tenant_id whenever it is missing in the port removal.

Change-Id: I7580ed2f545ad2d92b831b65dfbb34541bf465aa
Fixes: bug #1190020
(cherry picked from commit f392263ae8c89412ec8be6a13b3dd56abd129a8c)

as configuraitons are overwritten every run. Disabled the default apache module
vhost, and moved an equivalent into horizon.

Wrote rspec for changes.

Change-Id: Icdc792689935bfef3cf6d48cd862dee86558f579
Fixes: bug #1191647
"}, {'created': '2013-06-17 04:05:20.000000000', 'message': "Apache module won't overwrite default vhost

Duplicate configurations of port in default vhost cause constant reloading
as configuraitons are overwritten every run. Disabled the default apache module

commit_message:
Apache module won't overwrite default vhost

Duplicate configurations of port in default vhost cause constant reloading
as configuraitons are overwritten every run. Disabled the default apache module
vhost, and moved an equivalent into horizon.

Wrote rspec for changes.

Change-Id: Icdc792689935bfef3cf6d48cd862dee86558f579
Fixes: bug #1191647

commit_message:
Remove db api call from cycle.

This patch provide some optimization in db api
usage. New parameter 'get_network' added to
fixed_ip_get_by_host() method.
Also remove locals() from optimized method.

Change-Id: I4558954c4f817ceb9faaacaec91af318cc11f4a3

commit_message:
RPC: Add MessageSecurity implementation

Add Message Security[1] class and exceptions
Also add process-local Key Storage and Caching facility.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/MessageSecurity

Change-Id: I5f6204534c72df6833dd35547dfb6b844b1e0369
Implements: blueprint trusted-messaging

I think there are a lot of consistency problems that would need to be solved for this to work.

It needs to make sure it's patching the same version of the object on all backends.  Previous attempts at this kind of thing have required you to send the version of the object you want to patch, but just getting a quorum or the most recent version from the object servers might be enough and a little less onerous for the client.

It needs to handle the PATCH failing partway through, probably either by working on a copy of the object or by atomically saving the patch beside the object first, then applying it (and applying any oustanding patches on reads).

Even then, there's some weirdness like race conditions with concurrent PATCHes.  But as long as consistency is preserved, I could probably ignore that kind of stuff.

If you really want to support FUSE richly, it probably needs a method to truncate objects.  That could just be a header that's sent with the patch."}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-05-31 09:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@Chmouel Boudjnah
Correct me if I'm wrong but that page suggests replacing POST methods with PATCH. Currently the POST methods change the metadata of objects, replacing that with PATCH is problematic since PATCH is suppose to apply changes to the resource itself, not its metadata.

@Michael Barton
You're absolutely right about the "fail halfway through" part, however, this implementation (currently) only supports one change per request, so thats not an issue at the moment :)

Again, absolutely right about the truncate part. I had it in the implementation up until patch set 5 or so. I'm just not that sure that adding such a header is very REST-ish. I'd love to hear some thoughts on that though, can't say I'm a REST expert yet. Either way, from my very short experience I found that truncate is usually called with length=0. So its kinda silly (in my opinion, at least) to implement a truncate header just for that. 
Currently, my FUSE client just handles truncate(0) with empty PUT requests and everything works fine with that.

And to the hard part, consistency. Well, my intuition was that a quorum would be enough, but I think it is indeed time to check that. I'm currently writing some tests for this implementation but haven't got to the consistency part.
If you can suggest any specific scenarios to cover that, it'd be much appreciated!'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-08 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-08 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-06-08 17:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Restored

Adding unit-tests'}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-06-08 17:25:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-08 18:17:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30013/8/check/gate-swift-pep8/2669 : SUCCESS in 49s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/30013/8/check/gate-swift-docs/2499/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 02s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30013/8/check/gate-swift-python26/2747 : SUCCESS in 2m 32s

- http://logs.openstack.org/30013/8/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/28847 : SUCCESS in 19m 25s

- http://logs.openstack.org/30013/8/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/8945 : SUCCESS in 14m 39s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-13 00:32:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

I dunno; my big worry about the way this is done is all the MD5 recomputation, and more specifically, the disk IO needed for the MD5 recomputation.

If I upload a bunch of 5 GB objects to a Swift cluster and then start repeatedly PATCH-ing the first byte in each one, that's a metric crapton of disk IO, and it could seriously impact performance.

Maybe it's not actually that big a deal and I'm worrying too much, but it's something that concerns me.

Also, I think that a PATCH to a big object will block all other requests to the object server for a while since disk IO doesn't cause greenthread switching. You can ameliorate this by sticking some `sleep()` calls in the read-the-whole-file loop so that it plays nicely with others. (Note that this is only true when threads_per_disk is 0, but that's the default, so it's still important.)

Also also, and correct me if I'm wrong, but I don't think this'll work with container sync. That is, I don't think a PATCH-ed object in a synced container will get synced to the other side. I could easily be wrong here, though, since I haven't been through that code in a while."}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-06-14 15:39:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Samuel Merritt
Yeah, I understand what you mean about the MD5 computations.
On my first attempts I did not fix the 'etag', while not being aware of the auditor, and objects just kept getting quarantined.
The only other way I thought about was replacing the 'etag' with a list of md5 hashes for every page (or any other value thats not as big as the file and yet won't explode the storage needs) and then only change the relevant hash. But I don't think its such a good idea...
If there are any suggestions I'd love to hear them.
I will add that 'sleep()' you mentioned, though, sounds very reasonable.
But If you consider the alternative, which is issuing a full PUT request, you compute the MD5 sum anyway. So, both of them have that downside, but with PATCH you save 5GB of bandwidth (and time!).

About the container-sync, I have to admit I don't know, I have never used the container sync option. I will try it sometime next week and let you know what happens."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-06-14 15:55:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If I'm reading this correctly, this will patch the object in place, which is not a good idea for many reasons, but the biggest reason being replication.  Say a patch fails on any of the objects, replication will not know to replicate the file since it was in-place."}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-06-14 17:18:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Chuck Thier
Hmm, well I was under the impression that it would work the same way as overwriting PUT requests get replicated. I looked a bit further and now I see you're right, it won't work.

However, what if we call 'renamer' (actually, maybe even 'put') at the end of the PATCH handler? That would invalidate the hashes and replication would work the same way it does for overwriting PUT requests, right?

What other concerns do you have with in place writing?

Anyway, thanks for all the input guys, keep it coming. I hope you're not giving up on this! :)"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-15 00:19:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm not so much worried about the total disk IO; it's that the IO done in the cluster is not proportional to the IO done by the client.

For the client to do a PUT with a whole new object induces 5 GB of network IO in the client and also induces 15 GB network IO (5 each of proxy in, proxy out, backend in) / 5 GB disk IO in the cluster, for a total amplification of 3x network and 1x disk.

That means a client needs some Serious Bandwidth(tm) to induce enough cluster IO to cause a problem.

Now, consider a PATCH request to update byte 1 of a 5 GB object. Imagine the request weighs in at 1 KB. That'll result in 3 KB of network IO within the cluster and 5 GB of disk IO on the backend, for a total amplification of 3x network (again) and 1,000,000x disk. Yikes.

With a million-fold amplification factor, one guy on the other end of a dial-up modem connection can easily induce a gigantic pile of IO in a Swift cluster.

I dunno; maybe that's a thing people want and it's okay. It just seems to me like an awful lot of trust to place in users."}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2013-06-15 05:32:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I guess the actual hard parts of doing PATCH are making it transactional, making it consistent, and dealing with the extra i/o of re-hashing.  I don't think any of those problems have been addressed."}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-06-15 13:12:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Alright, so to sum up your concerns (as I understand them, please correct me if Im wrong):

1. Not breaking replication

2. Not breaking container-sync

3. Being transactional

4. Being consistent

5. I/O of rehashing

On 3, I believe I have already addressed this. Since I allow only a single change to be made with every request, I can't see any transactional problems happening. But if you disagree, I'd appreciate it if you could elaborate a bit on the matter. 

I believe I will be able to solve 1 and 2. However I think they might suffer the same IO problems that occur in 5.

On 4, I think requiring a quorum and using replication should suffice. However, we could also require the user to give the timestamp of the object he is patching. If its not the timestamp of the current object we could return an error message. Is that something that you'd feel more comfortable with?

So, as far as I can see we have 3 options:

1. Fix replication and container sync and decide the extra IO is something we can live with.

2. Fix replication and container sync and change the way hashes are saved. Save a list of hashes for parts of the object and only rehash whats needed. 

3. Abandon PATCHing of objects.

So, I dunno if theres a voting process or it's the project leader's decision. I'm all in for working hard on this but I need to know whether this is something you think is going in the right direction."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-15 23:20:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Someone kindly reminded me that Swift already supports the POST verb with X-Copy-From, so IO amplification is apparently a thing we're okay with.

As far as transactionality (specifically atomicity) goes, I don't think that restricting yourself to a single write takes care of it. Even if you do the timestamp checking, then two simultaneous (or close enough) PATCH requests to different offsets of the same object could wind up both patching, when what you really want is for either patch A or patch B to be applied, but not both.

Now I'm going to speculate on a possible way to have PATCH work that (I think) avoids all the problems hit so far. I'll probably miss something, so be on guard.

What if PATCH support were implemented in the proxy server instead of the object server? Basically, PATCH would look like:

* start a GET for the object
* start 3 PUTs for the same object
* stream the object's body from the GET response and write it to the PUT requests, only modifying the relevant bytes when you come to them

By writing it in terms of already-existing operations, it may solve most of your problems:

* works with replication: yes, because the existing operations work with replication. 
* container sync: probably? dunno.
* transactional: yes, because the existing operations are transactional
* consistent: yes, at least as much as the existing operations are consistent
* I/O load: eh, screw it, we've already got X-Copy-From

You also gain some benefits, like being able to support multiple ranges in a single PATCH, and not conflicting with hypothetical future pie-in-the-sky features like on-disk object compression or encryption or whatever other crazy things people might do with the on-disk representation of objects.

Also, one note regardless of what you choose to do: HTTP gives you the header "If-Match" (RFC 2616 section 14.24), and I would require the client to send an If-Match header for PATCH requests. The header's value is the Etag of the object, and that's a much stronger condition than X-Timestamp IMHO. It lets a client say "patch exactly this object and no other" with a strength that X-Timestamp doesn't have. (And if you have a reckless client, "If-Match: *" is HTTP-ese for "shut up and do it".)'}, {'account_id': 7601, 'date': '2013-06-16 06:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Hmm, an interesting idea. Getting the same outcome with less code and being more "future proof". I'm not quite sure it solves the transactional problem you stated, but the If Match header is a thing ill look into.

I'll start working on it today, see how it turns out and open a new change set for it. I guess I'll mark this as abandoned for now, at least until we can can compare it with the new approach.'}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-06-17 16:24:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I'm not very fond of the current COPY (and including the implementation of POST based on COPY), and would prefer that we not continue that type of pattern."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-25 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-25 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

"}, {'created': '2013-05-29 21:55:02.000000000', 'message': 'Introducing PATCH support for Swift.

An attempt to allow Swift to host efficient cloud-sync services.
Currently, an attempt to implement such services will result in a waste of bandwidth when objects are changed.
This happens because on each change, the entire object has to be re-uploaded.
Therefore, implementing a "PATCH" method for objects, allows us to send only the change and not the entire file, saving precious bandwidth.

In addition, we can throw in a FUSE based client as a proof of concept.
Combining the two, one can "mount" a Swift container onto the filesystem and any user-land application can work with those objects as if they were normal files.

The range in the object to be patched is supplied via a Range header. Currently, only one range is supported.
If the request is successful, the data that was in the given range will be replaced by the data in the request.
If the end of the range is bigger than the size of the object, the object's size will increase.

Example request:
PATCH /v1/<account>/<container>/<object> HTTP/1.1
Host: storage.swiftdrive.com
X-Auth-token: XXXX
Range: bytes=0-10
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Content-Length: 10
[...data to patch...]

Responses can be "Bad Request" if no range or more than one range is supplied.
On success, "No Content" is returned.

Changes are made to:
[-]object controller: redirect requests to the nodes
[-]object server: patch an object based on the "range" header and the content.
[-]container server: updates the container's metadata based on the changes made to the object.

Implements:  bp/object-patch-support
Change-Id: I8f7951ac367e516e81d13bc680c0fe16630b2133

Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Content-Length: 10
[...data to patch...]

Responses can be "Bad Request" if no range or more than one range is supplied.
On success, "No Content" is returned.

Changes are made to:
[-]object controller: redirect requests to the nodes
[-]object server: patch an object based on the "range" header and the content.
[-]container server: updates the container's metadata based on the changes made to the object.

Implements:  bp/object-patch-support

commit_message:
Introducing PATCH support for Swift.

An attempt to allow Swift to host efficient cloud-sync services.
Currently, an attempt to implement such services will result in a waste of bandwidth when objects are changed.
This happens because on each change, the entire object has to be re-uploaded.
Therefore, implementing a "PATCH" method for objects, allows us to send only the change and not the entire file, saving precious bandwidth.

In addition, we can throw in a FUSE based client as a proof of concept.
Combining the two, one can "mount" a Swift container onto the filesystem and any user-land application can work with those objects as if they were normal files.

The range in the object to be patched is supplied via a Range header. Currently, only one range is supported.
If the request is successful, the data that was in the given range will be replaced by the data in the request.
If the end of the range is bigger than the size of the object, the object's size will increase.

Example request:
PATCH /v1/<account>/<container>/<object> HTTP/1.1
Host: storage.swiftdrive.com
X-Auth-token: XXXX
Range: bytes=0-10
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
Content-Length: 10
[...data to patch...]

Responses can be "Bad Request" if no range or more than one range is supplied.
On success, "No Content" is returned.

Changes are made to:
[-]object controller: redirect requests to the nodes
[-]object server: patch an object based on the "range" header and the content.
[-]container server: updates the container's metadata based on the changes made to the object.

Implements:  bp/object-patch-support
Change-Id: I8f7951ac367e516e81d13bc680c0fe16630b2133

commit_message:
Remove support for rackspace classic.

We don't use classic in the pool anymore. Also, it is possible to
use rackspace without the special auth flag, and we currently do that
for our rackspace nova pool. So - remove the code which support
non-compliant clouds

Change-Id: I03709100030bd36960da5cacc2759a3e2113f50c

commit_message:
Fix hacking style violations.

As part of this, move utility libraries and tests into the
devstack_gate package. This gives them a bit of namespacing,
and allows us to avoid relative imports, which will make hacking
pleased.

Change-Id: I22475b38a02598d88f0441c217a773897823a832

'}, {'created': '2013-06-14 22:09:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add test for NoVNC proxy

commit_message:
Add test for NoVNC proxy

The NoVNC proxy is not covered in any existing tests, which
results in things like bug 1190628.  This adds a very basic
test that checks if the NoVNC proxy is at least started.

Change-Id: I026f8712adda01a663f2948ff9734cff9e2b80c6

If we're going to make this change--and I think it makes sense since it's officially deprecated--might be worth fixing the whole code base and adding a gate-check.

Otherwise, more cases are going to slip in since not every reviewer is aware.

This gate-check might make sense in pep8 directly since it's an official Python decision; though, if they're reluctant, can always toss it in as a nova specific check."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-15 12:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is probably another good python3 compat check for hacking, as assertEquals is upstream deprecated for 2.7, and presumably not in python3.

But like others, I think that cleanups for style like this without a path towards automatic enforcement (i.e. hacking rule in process) just causes churn.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-17 22:07:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Setting group ownership of /dev/kvm for RHEL-alikes

This is required for CentOS 6.4 to successfully launch instances.

Change-Id: I4d19220b520f669e59a0469edd36700ce9e03f34

commit_message:
Add support for --os-cacert

Handle --os-cacert and OS_CACERT to supply CA root certificate.  This is the
same semantics used by the other core clients.

Change-Id: I63a204d3f0a481b87f8795b5681a3db35fb3e503

bug #1188202

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 06:03:02.000000000', 'message': 'Allow OVS default veth MTU to be configured.

In some environments where a packet is dropped when a VLAN tag is
added to the packet, you need to increase the MTU size of veth
interfaces to 1504.

Fixes: bug #1075336
Change-Id: I4f03b4cdc571a462096d419d6dd8324cf096156b
'}]
commit_message:
Allow OVS default veth MTU to be configured.

In some environments where a packet is dropped when a VLAN tag is
added to the packet, you need to increase the MTU size of veth
interfaces to 1504.

Fixes: bug #1075336
Change-Id: I4f03b4cdc571a462096d419d6dd8324cf096156b

commit_message:
Add support for swift user/key authentication

By default the swift backup service uses keystone authentication to
communicate with the swift endpoint. This patch adds three optional
parameters to allow username/key authentication

Change-Id: I54ad7d91785ade5375f317aceb80b3374b59f5fe

commit_message:
Puppet Forge release 2.0.0

  Marks the commit that the branch stable/grizzly and the 2.0.0 tag is
  cut from.  Also adds the pkg directory to .gitignore to prevent
  accidental committing of Forge artifacts to the repository.

commit_message:
Unset default signing dir

Unset default signing dir to allow the keystoneclient to set its own.
The specified /etc/swift location is not ideal and breaks on recent
keystoneclients

Change-Id: I16aadb77ee85e84645fe6745760a2c6edee49c2b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-25 03:16:54.000000000', 'message': 'Document the OVS service restart

When installing Quantum OVS agent, the OVS service might not be properly
started due to a missing kernel module (compiled using DKMS). Make sure
that the service is (re)started before restarting the agent.

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/33787

Change-Id: Ic049b1698c2176b2adfa5f32ca6253b6484d966a
'}]
commit_message:
Document the OVS service restart

When installing Quantum OVS agent, the OVS service might not be properly
started due to a missing kernel module (compiled using DKMS). Make sure
that the service is (re)started before restarting the agent.

Cherry-picked from https://review.openstack.org/33787

Change-Id: Ic049b1698c2176b2adfa5f32ca6253b6484d966a

necessary)

commit_message:
replace use of dhcp_lease_time with dhcp_lease_duration

Having 2 separate dhcp lease period flags (dhcp_lease_duration
used by the quantum db plugin, and dhcp_lease_time used by the
dnsmasq dhcp agent) means that you could potentially have different
lease periods being set, and used by different parts of the codebase.

It seems to me there is no real need to have 2 separate flags, so this
commit basically replaces references to dhcp_lease_time (which is used
by the dnsmasq dhcpagent) with dhcp_lease_duration. This way, there
is only one flag to set, and both the quantum db plugin and dnsmasq
dhcp agent will use the same lease period.

Change-Id: Ia99dfa9284b6e737144f61a80c59cd898c0949bb
Fixes: bug #1192550

commit_message:
Add _create_volume to ThinLVMVolumeDriver

Previously, _create_volume from LVMISCSIDriver would be called
when the volume manager calls create_volume_from_snapshot.

Fixes bug: 1192601

(cherry picked from commit 79a402d07502ac34bc0ec485b21b0be50ba807a7)

Conflicts:
	cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py

Change-Id: I5cca287e8204c4647a5f09df961d9a76d0b38c42

Fix bug where consoleauth depended on remote conductor service

Fixes bug 1186123

Conductor API was being imported directly so ignoring use_local FLAG

Change-Id: I055a5301d4c18d201d67f114047f503114751603
(cherry picked from commit 6c6e43e466a5383b3ef3c852c9b2749f0fad64dc)

commit_message:
Converts 'router' section to lowercase in bigswitch config

The restproxy.ini file contained an uppercase section
which is converted to lowercase by this patch to match
existing naming conventions.

Change-Id: Ib8eb69406cae3898c4c9f3fd106f8c7ffef06f01
Fixes: bug #1194296

commit_message:
Build a heat tempest test image.

This will enable heat tests which rely on a test image being
configured.

It will also take some time to build the image during gating jobs,
until source images are cached on the devstack image.

Change-Id: I1e6edb52624ad52c1f4c838c33935b74f943acd8

subject: Adds support for object server redirection responses
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-23 22:42:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Preface: This is my opinion and counts the same as any other core dev.

I don't like the additional complexity this introduces or is paving the way for.

I don't like (eventually) loading the ring in the object server workers when it does not now.

In my opinion, the object server should simply store, retrieve, and delete objects and provide the minimal extra functions necessary (such as providing information about what is on disk for replicators).

I believe more complex logic should be in the proxy and ring code.

Object variations wouldn't need redirection to be implemented.

Ring version reporting can be (and already is being) done external to the object server (which doesn't load the ring now).

Storage tiers seem better implemented by ring features to me."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-23 22:44:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-23 22:02:37.000000000', 'message': "Adds support for object server redirection responses

- allows for the object server to respond to a GET request that would have otherwise been 'not found' with infomration that the proxy can use to potentially locate the response
- provides a capabilty that future features can leverage but does not actually implement any redicetion scenarios itself
- can be used by blueprints such as 'object-variation' as well as 'send-ring-version' and 'storage-tiers'
- on the object side, added plumbing for the object service to add redirection info to the response via new headers and reply with a 301 status
- on the proxy side, detects a redirection response and retries the GET request using the info provided by the reirect response limiting the number of redirections per reqeust to three
- tested by temp adding a test header to trigger redirection, tested found/not found with and without redirection including assuring the protection for redictetion limits is functional
- colleage will be working on 'send-ring'version' shortly

blueprint support-storage-server-redirects

Change-Id: Ie4cc8d1f85a6528f2394943d94ce9ab580dc8001
"}]
commit_message:
Adds support for object server redirection responses

- allows for the object server to respond to a GET request that would have otherwise been 'not found' with infomration that the proxy can use to potentially locate the response
- provides a capabilty that future features can leverage but does not actually implement any redicetion scenarios itself
- can be used by blueprints such as 'object-variation' as well as 'send-ring-version' and 'storage-tiers'
- on the object side, added plumbing for the object service to add redirection info to the response via new headers and reply with a 301 status
- on the proxy side, detects a redirection response and retries the GET request using the info provided by the reirect response limiting the number of redirections per reqeust to three
- tested by temp adding a test header to trigger redirection, tested found/not found with and without redirection including assuring the protection for redictetion limits is functional
- colleage will be working on 'send-ring'version' shortly

blueprint support-storage-server-redirects

Change-Id: Ie4cc8d1f85a6528f2394943d94ce9ab580dc8001

[{'created': '2013-06-22 14:57:13.000000000', 'message': 'Extends SWIFT loopback device size to 2G

The volume-upload-image test requires a cinder volume to be
uploaded in glance, see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33999/
Given that glance is configured to use swift as backend, we
extend the swift loopback device from 1G to be 2G (with thanks to
fungi and zhiyan who helped troubleshoot this.

Change-Id: I108b4ffeafcb1983745cbb20e88b85393c31464e
'}]
commit_message:
Extends SWIFT loopback device size to 2G

The volume-upload-image test requires a cinder volume to be
uploaded in glance, see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33999/
Given that glance is configured to use swift as backend, we
extend the swift loopback device from 1G to be 2G (with thanks to
fungi and zhiyan who helped troubleshoot this.

Change-Id: I108b4ffeafcb1983745cbb20e88b85393c31464e

commit_message:
Make cli tests use etc/tempest.conf

The default cli_dir value (/usr/local/bin) does not work on some
systems (e.g. Fedora). The cli tests did not use the etc/tempest.conf
as others do.

The patch moves the cli configuration into tempest.config module.

Change-Id: Ifaf8315eaf179d05481542042385e816e0b80693

commit_message:
Add the task to the accumulator before running.

Instead of only adding the task to the rollback
accumulator after it has ran it is useful to add
it to the accumulator before it runs so that if
said task fails while running it can get a chance
at undoing anything it might have done.

Change-Id: I5c9cf2fd194e3b42639d84a0d9dfed3a3b5a797d

[{'created': '2013-06-24 21:32:42.000000000', 'message': 'Remove project ID from the URI

This patch modifies the WSGI routes to pull the project ID from
the headers (X-Project-ID) rather than from the URI. Once this
is merged, the implementation will be fully compliant with
the V1 API spec.

Note that clients will be required to include X-Project-ID in
requests since there will not always be a 1:1 relationship
between auth token and project. To support this scenario, the
service provider will also need to perform policy enforcement
in a proxy or in middleware.

Implements: blueprint v1-api
Change-Id: Ib0b1218a98521b903643f3446d2192cddde135a7
'}, {'created': '2013-06-24 21:32:42.000000000', 'message': 'Remove project ID from the URI

This patch modifies the WSGI routes to pull the project ID from
the headers (X-Project-ID) rather than from the URI. Once this
is merged, the implementation will be fully compliant with
the V1 API spec.

Note that clients will be required to include X-Project-ID in
requests since there will not always be a 1:1 relationship
between auth token and project. To support this scenario, the
service provider will also need to perform policy enforcement
in a proxy or in middleware.

Implements: blueprint v1-api
Change-Id: Ib0b1218a98521b903643f3446d2192cddde135a7
'}]
commit_message:
Remove project ID from the URI

This patch modifies the WSGI routes to pull the project ID from
the headers (X-Project-ID) rather than from the URI. Once this
is merged, the implementation will be fully compliant with
the V1 API spec.

Note that clients will be required to include X-Project-ID in
requests since there will not always be a 1:1 relationship
between auth token and project. To support this scenario, the
service provider will also need to perform policy enforcement
in a proxy or in middleware.

Implements: blueprint v1-api
Change-Id: Ib0b1218a98521b903643f3446d2192cddde135a7

commit_message:
Add note about checks have community support

This project is only trying to enforce the agreed upon style guide, not
dictate it.  We do not want a new check added if there is any doubt the
check from the community.  Because this project has very a limited
number of reviewers we have to be extra careful about dictating style to the
rest of the community. Consensus in hacking reviewers is not community
consensus.

Change-Id: Id7aaefb8fb98b365f45c8eeb3aa53de02b9cb4e6

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-24 06:05:19.000000000', 'message': 'Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.tests.*

Using of locals() for formatting string is a nasty thing because:
1) It is not so clear as using explicit dicts
2) It could produce hidden errors during refactoring
3) Changing name of variable causes change in message
4) Creating a lot of unused variables

Fix bug 1171936

Change-Id: I67aa5bff650b55484ca76adf5be8555f72a4c426
'}]
commit_message:
Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.tests.*

Using of locals() for formatting string is a nasty thing because:
1) It is not so clear as using explicit dicts
2) It could produce hidden errors during refactoring
3) Changing name of variable causes change in message
4) Creating a lot of unused variables

Fix bug 1171936

Change-Id: I67aa5bff650b55484ca76adf5be8555f72a4c426

I am just wondering, if we might raise the InstancePowerOffFailure exception from hard_shutdown_vm. This way we could get rid of the return values, and we'll get the same exception in _resize_ensure_vm_is_shutdown for free. _resize_ensure_vm_is_shutdown is the only one who checks the return value. Also vmware and baremetal guys seem to raise this exception from power_off."}, {'account_id': 7531, 'date': '2013-06-21 15:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

I see that hard_shutdown_vm method is used in many places.
_destroy, _resize_ensure_vm_is_shutdown, power_off and rescue.
If changed the contract of hard_shut_down_vm, I would have to handle the exception differently at each of these places. 
I think it makes sense to have this change here, and then make changes on others incrementally. Once we reach a point where all the consumers rely on the return value of hard_shutdown_vm, we can safely raise exception and catch it.
Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-21 19:55:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
XenApi virt driver should throw exception on failure

Virt xenapi driver does not throw InstancePowerOffFailure exception
on a failure while destroying an instance.
_shutdown_instance in compute manager expects InstancePowerOffFailure
and reraises it.
This ensures that instances are not wrongly marked as deleted.

Change-Id: Id57f48a00202bd5ed3125f8e4396a51c12e142cb
Fixes: bug #1190076

commit_message:
Get several messages by ID using a queue filter parameter

This modifies the way multiple messages are queried by ID such that
the IDs are now listed as a query parameter for GET requestes to
a queue resource.

Change-Id: If1245bdb7a75614311f5beb61f8835faa4521de8
Implements: blueprint v1-api

subject: Add check for end of title line of commit messages
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-20 09:33:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-20 09:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This came about because tripleo folks were actually rigidly enforcing the wrong style, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/TripleO

 * Periods at the end of git commit messages. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33262  (SpamapS, markmc)
 *# With the 50 char limit, space is at a premium on the first line
 *# The first line is often used as the Subject: in [PATCH] emails - subject lines in emails generally don't end in a period
 *# Examples in https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_GIT_commit_message_structure don't end in period
 *# Another common reference on git commit messages http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html doesn't either
 *# In git's own git repo, 1.43% of commit messages in the last year ended in a period
 *# I'm not aware of any other OpenStack project which enforces this - if anything, I think we should enforce "no period"'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-20 09:35:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/33789/2/check/gate-hacking-pep8/129 : SUCCESS in 38s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/33789/2/check/gate-hacking-docs/129/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 43s

- http://logs.openstack.org/33789/2/check/gate-hacking-integration-nova/22 : SUCCESS in 2m 22s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-20 16:42:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Awesome, I definitely agree with this.  It would be nice to send something to the dev mailing list giving a heads up on this too.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-21 22:23:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

heh, nits are nice :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 22:23:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 22:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 22:26:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/33789/2/gate/gate-hacking-docs/134/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 55s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33789/2/gate/gate-hacking-pep8/134 : SUCCESS in 57s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33789/2/gate/gate-hacking-python26/132 : SUCCESS in 59s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33789/2/gate/gate-hacking-python27/134 : SUCCESS in 47s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33789/2/gate/gate-hacking-integration-nova/27 : SUCCESS in 2m 36s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-06-24 20:26:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It would have been nice for this to be discussed rather than dropping into the communal standards without warning; the prior documentation *did not* require a period, and the reference that was sourced that doesn't use them is one in the git-via-email world which is not how OpenStack does *any* of it's git communications, so the 'gets used like subject line of emails' point is entirely irrelevant. 

In TripleO we have been using a period because the first line of the commit message acts like the first line of a docstring: it is a pithy description of the object it describes. Docstrings are also space limited, and yet PEP8 happily requires good sentence structure and grammar there.

tl;dr - this is an unpythonic change, and the lack of discussion is quite annoying."}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2013-06-24 20:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Also not that space is limited to 50 characters by choice, not necessity (the very same external reference about git commit messages pointed out that 50 is not a hard limit). It is a hard limit for us... because we chose to make it so.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-24 21:46:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I agree with lifeless, this should have an mailing list thread, otherwise I think this is worth reverting.  As we don't want this repo to dictate style only enforce it."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-24 21:51:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, I went and posted the whole thing here: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-June/010837.html'}]

The end of the title line of commit messages should not end with a
period. This is because space is limited to 50 chars and because we

the correct style is.

Change-Id: I162ed090fbaef4f111792fdb89b31c2cab993b22

commit_message:
Add check for end of title line of commit messages

The end of the title line of commit messages should not end with a
period. This is because space is limited to 50 chars and because we
treat this line like the subject line of emails.

Add this incredibly nitpicky style check to avoid any doubt over what
the correct style is.

Change-Id: I162ed090fbaef4f111792fdb89b31c2cab993b22

commit_message:
Don't keep the state/version in the task name.

Instead of having individual entries for the task
that change with the state name + version, we should
instead just keep the same task name but update the metadata
about the states the task has gone through instead. Also
store the task version in the same metadata and warn users
when the versions may be incompat.

This makes it easier to see what a task has done
without having to know all the states it has gone
through (just to find the task details about that
task) as well as being able to detect version issues.

Change-Id: Ia6b9400394212230905341d205d966dfdee5dfdf

the database.

commit_message:
Ensure domains that fail to create are cleaned

This helps to reduce the cases where creating a domain in the configured
backend fails for whatever reason.

Longer term, we need a better fix to this issue for all the backend
modifying calls.

Change-Id: Id194c3df51323ed52ce2e694e5ac8a1b0a8b9a23

commit_message:
Optionally reject messages on exception.

Rather than blindly ack() all messages, consumers can be created
that reject() the message if an exception occurs in the callback.

Currently only implemented in kombu driver.

Change-Id: I308dd794b50966e3a189d31b2b51fdac36cd7d3a

commit_message:
Update kombu and anyjson

Update the kombu requirement based on the new
value in the global requirements list.

The new version of kombu we are using depends on
anyjson>=0.3.3.

Related to bug #1134575

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

Change-Id: I36211a2730bfc712e189d39893ab2af513ce3ba9
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Fix serialization of iterable types

So far, we have not supported serialization of iterable type
arguments to RPC methods. However, the recent change to pass
args as a tuple instead of forcing everything to kwargs means
that serialization of non-keyword args is broken. This patch
adds that support, as well as tests for the serializer, which
should have been there in the first place.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: Ie02fffd89d9b79b4bc8270c14b2860c0e37d7a92

commit_message:
Fix orphaned instance from get_by_uuid() and _from_db_object()

We need to set _context on the Instance object we create during
get_by_uuid(), but more specifically during _from_db_object().
In order to properly initialize things like nested objects that
themselves need a _context, we should pass it to _from_db_object()
always.

Same thing for InstanceInfoCache.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I09ab6b5d7d8961b69294536885e8432943b3a611

commit_message:
Do not send traceback to clients by default

eventlet.wsgi.server contains a "debug" param which is True by default.
This sends tracebacks to the client on 500 errors, which is not
desirable for security reasons.

Set this to be False by default.

Fixes bug 1192132

Change-Id: Ib54fb79128c6922f7a38339c4256f0e4c81e1665

commit_message:
python3: Strutils is not needed

strutils is used to safely encode and decode unicode strings
for python2.7. Since unicode strings are the default in python3,
ignore the use of strutils when running with python3.

Change-Id: I9a8e296b4f2153b1ef4302a7dcd797fbb4561c35
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

way to turn on debug mode. This change simply adds two attributes for

Change-Id: Ica613abb4e2d3719acaf1c9a4cb01fe92fd11774

commit_message:
Allow for setting debug and verbose config options

Right now, nova.conf hard codes verbose = true. Similarly there is no
way to turn on debug mode. This change simply adds two attributes for
both verbose and debug and makes use of them in the nova.conf template.

Change-Id: Ica613abb4e2d3719acaf1c9a4cb01fe92fd11774

[{'created': '2013-06-10 13:17:03.000000000', 'message': 'Correct API for listing user roles & role assignments

The v3 API specification listed two api calls relating to roles that
are, in fact, un-implemented in the Grizzly code, namely:

GET /users/{user_id}/roles
GET /roles/{role_id}/users

These are replaced with a more generalized call for listing role
assignments, allowing for filtering based on domain, project, role
and user.

bp get-role-assignments
Fixes bug #1183430
Fixes bug #1183433

Change-Id: I8d3e61aab053f230fdc277f7847a58d834694ac4

commit_message:
Correct API for listing user roles & role assignments

The v3 API specification listed two api calls relating to roles that
are, in fact, un-implemented in the Grizzly code, namely:

GET /users/{user_id}/roles
GET /roles/{role_id}/users

These are replaced with a more generalized call for listing role
assignments, allowing for filtering based on domain, project, role,
user and group.

bp get-role-assignments
Fixes bug #1183430
Fixes bug #1183433

Change-Id: I8d3e61aab053f230fdc277f7847a58d834694ac4

The reason tox takes a long time is two-fold: On the first run it has to create a virtual environment, which can take anywhere from 5 to 30+ minutes depending on the project and the system.  The other reason is that it just takes a long time to run all of the test cases in some of the projects.  This is probably information that can go in the wiki though.'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-06-19 22:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thanks for the explanation, Ben, I have added it to the wiki.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-20 08:16:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Anita'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2013-06-20 14:48:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I noticed that the Nova section of the testing wiki is way out of date.  I was going to update it, but I'm wondering if we really want a separate section for Nova now.  I feel like the idea is to make all of the projects work as similarly as possible so we don't need specific instructions for each.  Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-06-20 15:11:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Ben said:
"I feel like the idea is to make all of the projects work as similarly as possible so we don't need specific instructions for each."

That is certainly the direction I am heading. It allows the contributor to use the same commands on any project encouraging cross-project contribution (I hope).

I think the wiki can be the place where people who want to retain the run_tests.sh script can share the instructions for its use. So run_tests.sh isn't eliminated, it is an option for testing.

Having said that, I do think that whatever information is on the wiki about Nova (and Swift) does need to be current. I didn't want to just summarily delete information when I was making additions.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-20 18:03:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

It would be nice to make this a rst file so github can make it look pretty.  Also rst source is easy to read

https://github.com/openstack-dev/hacking/blob/master/HACKING.rst

https://raw.github.com/openstack-dev/hacking/master/HACKING.rst'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-06-20 19:31:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

If we want an .rst file, I can make it an .rst file.'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-06-20 20:20:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6316, 'date': '2013-06-20 20:21:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Creates a new file TESTING.rst.

Creates a new file called TESTING.rst making the file discoverable.

Contents of the file include very generic instructions to get newcomers
started with testing. File also includes links, including the OpenStack
wiki page on testing, encouraging the curious to access greater options
for testing individual projects as well as greater flexibility in testing.

Change-Id: I57ab249133eccd38fa5302809e06172ed6a7d89e

'}, {'created': '2013-06-21 02:25:55.000000000', 'message': "Handle NoMoreFixedIps in _shutdown_instance.

Bug 1192893

If no fixed ips is found, continue to perform the rest of the instance
shutdown, instead of propogating the exception.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a network
2. Reserve all fixed ips of the network
3. Try to create an instance but failed
4. Try to delete the instance

Results:
Cannot delete the instance due to the 'NoMoreFixedIps' exception.

Change-Id: I42776c427773f1f81c16062a9aaa54850ec68bfd
"}]
commit_message:
Handle NoMoreFixedIps in _shutdown_instance.

Bug 1192893

If no fixed ips is found, continue to perform the rest of the instance
shutdown, instead of propogating the exception.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a network
2. Reserve all fixed ips of the network
3. Try to create an instance but failed
4. Try to delete the instance

Results:
Cannot delete the instance due to the 'NoMoreFixedIps' exception.

Change-Id: I42776c427773f1f81c16062a9aaa54850ec68bfd

commit_message:
Set keystone token backend to sql.

Because the table could grow forever, also add a cron job to flush tokens
every two hours.

Due to bug #1188378 we need to use percona-toolkit's pt-archiver to
clean out the table on mysql.

Fixes bug #1188301

Change-Id: I90aac347993ee741231fbfb99a32dc6e3f3a75ec
