'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-05-31 11:27:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

we shouldn't use 422, that's the crux of my -1.

for readability, what about using the HTTP numbers instead of the webob exceptions? It's in the API path, so I feel like it's more descriptive to talk about them in actual HTTP numbers. The decorator would use these, then map them to exceptions under the cover. It would also make the code a little more compact."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-05-31 12:28:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Do you have any suggestions for the appropriate return code? Does a fairly generic 500 sound reasonable to you - since its an unexpected error its not clear whether its bad client data or the server misbehaving.

I agree its probably better specify the expected errors in terms of HTTP codes. May have to cleanup a few cases where extensions rely on things like KeyError implicitly being converted to and HTTPBadRequest, but thats probably a good thing to do anyway.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-03 02:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-03 02:33:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Patch set 4 returns 500 (internal server error) on an unexpected error instead of 413. Also expected errors are now specified in terms of HTTP status codes instead exceptions classes which makes specifying them more succinct.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-03 03:19:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

commit_message:
Adds expected_errors decorator for API v3

Adds an expected_errors decorator for v3 API methods which allows
the specification of what exceptions can be raised within the
method. If an unexpected error occurs a 500 is instead returned
which plus a request to file a bug report

Partially implements blueprint v3-api-expected-errors

Change-Id: I5723e576b30b47744394517cdb1ff6bab1d8f78b

David, the Jenkins failure was due to pep8 violations.

I pulled down your change to master and tested this version of the method, it works well, I think you should use it:

    def test_invalid_memory_mb(self):
        """Check negative and decimal memory_mb number can't be accepted"""
        # have to unset the stubs so the create method is actually tested
        self.stubs.UnsetAll()
        self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, flavors.create, "abcd",
                          -512, 2, 1, 1, 1234, 512, 1, True)
        self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, flavors.create, "abcd",

commit_message:
Add invalid number checking in flavor creation api

Flavor creation api doesn't check whether 'memory_mb'
argument number is integer,add invalid number checking
into the flavor creation function to remind the user to
input right value

Fixes bug #1171278

Change-Id: I8308f66c485d8c872864661148e9eac7b685e406

'}, {'created': '2013-06-20 23:05:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add per-instance qemu/kvm version checking

Bug 1193146

Added support for querying the hypervisor version of a running
instance using Qemu QMP, sinc ethere was no way to get this
information via a native Libvirt API call. The check on whether the
requirements are met for live snapshots was updated to pass
instance_name, so that we can make the determination properly.

Change-Id: Ife5d2fd768a34dabf25a1bfc24e54bd6db762c89
'}, {'created': '2013-06-21 23:27:34.000000000', 'message': 'Perform additional check before live snapshotting

Bug 1193146

Move blockJobAbort() out of the _live_snapshot function, such that
it continues to terminate existing jobs, while also doubling as a
method for confirming that our version of Qemu/KVM is new enough to
execute a _live_snapshot.

Change-Id: Ife5d2fd768a34dabf25a1bfc24e54bd6db762c89
'}]
commit_message:
Perform additional check before live snapshotting

Bug 1193146

Move blockJobAbort() out of the _live_snapshot function, such that
it continues to terminate existing jobs, while also doubling as a
method for confirming that our version of Qemu/KVM is new enough to
execute a _live_snapshot.

Change-Id: Ife5d2fd768a34dabf25a1bfc24e54bd6db762c89

commit_message:
Version response compatible with Folsom

This change adds <link> elements to the <version id="v2.0">
element in the version response to be compatible with the
response given by the Keystone server in the Folsom release.

Fixes bug 1187101

Change-Id: Ida71e2dbe3cf432d429fb739e68a83d7e009ca40

commit_message:
Modify _assertEqualListsOfObjects() function.

Function _assertEqualListsOfObjects() changed in order to compare lists of
objects without `id` key. It can be usefull if we have no `id` in test data.

Change-Id: Ic3d599166e5a83969ef804bc9f7801cd2c9d0770

subject: Add reload_config_files function
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1994, 'name': 'Zhongyue Luo', 'email': 'zhongyue.luo@gmail.com', 'username': 'zyluo'}, {'_account_id': 4458, 'name': 'Shane Wang', 'email': 'shane.wang@intel.com', 'username': 'shane-wang'}, {'_account_id': 4491, 'name': 'Lianhao Lu', 'email': 'lianhao.lu@intel.com', 'username': 'lianhao-lu'}, {'_account_id': 5638, 'name': 'Davanum Srinivas', 'email': 'davanum@gmail.com', 'username': 'dims-v'}, {'_account_id': 7642, 'name': 'Fengqian Gao', 'email': 'fengqian.gao@intel.com', 'username': 'Fengqian'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2013-06-08 08:38:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Please see the comment. Others seems fine to me.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2013-06-08 08:39:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

one more in commit message.'}, {'account_id': 7642, 'date': '2013-06-09 01:54:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4491, 'date': '2013-06-09 02:26:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

looks ok to me.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:38:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

The patch is nice and straightforward and probably works just fine.

However, there are some pretty difficult issues here. I'll put them in a comment separate from the straightforward comments inline."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, first - why would the API for this not be __call__()

i.e. why can't we support doing something like this:

  cfg.CONF(cfg.CONF.args)

Perhaps there's something I'm missing here?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:49:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Another slightly tricky issue is that we have to support reloading configuration files without causing the service to exit

Maybe we need to catch SystemExit here and rollback to our previous state ...

But then again, if we don't allow people to change the command line when reloading ... I *think* we shouldn't be able to cause a SystemExit error. We need to double and triple check that assumption, though.

But that raises the question of the semantics of reload() if there is an error ... what state is the ConfigOpts object left in if an exception is raised? IMHO, we should ensure it is always left in the original state if that happens"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:18:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Another concern is related to failure handling semantics ... atomicity

I can't think of a common case whereby eventlet would schedule a different greenthread while we're in the middle of executing reload_config_files() - because we're just reading files, I don't think anything should block (a mkfifo created config file would be one possibility, but eventlet doesn't appear to monkey patch file() or open() to handle this case)

But, not everyone using this library has to use eventlet ...

What happens if you have multiple native threads running and one thread attempts to read a value from ConfigOpts while we're in the middle of reload_config_files() ? For example, right after we do:

  self._namespace = _Namespace(self)

another thread could attempt to read a value

Maybe the fix for error handling will help us achieve atomicity ... i.e. we would not set self._namespace until we had finished parsing everything"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-10 22:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Finally, there's a more subtle issue that we could probably leave for another time ...

Imagine some code that reads two related configuration values

  if CONF.some_thing_enabled:
      do_something(CONF.dangerous_mode_of_some_thing)

a user could have:

  some_thing_enabled=True
  dangerous_mode_of_some_thing=False

and change to:

  some_thing_enabled=False
  dangerous_mode_of_some_thing=True

You would expect "dangerous mode" is never enabled, but there is a race condition where the code can read:

  some_thing_enabled=True
  dangerous_mode_of_some_thing=True

i.e. if the config files are reload between reading the two config options

I'd imagine we'd need to support something like:

  CONF.lock()
  try:
      if CONF.some_thing_enabled:
          do_something(CONF.dangerous_mode_of_some_thing)
  finally:
      CONF.unlock()

or better:

  CONF.lock()
  try:
      enabled = CONF.some_thing_enabled:
      dangerous_mode = CONF.dangerous_mode_of_some_thing
  finally:
      CONF.unlock()

  if enabled:
    do_something(dangerous_mode)


or even better:

  with :CONF.lock()
      enabled = CONF.some_thing_enabled:
      dangerous_mode = CONF.dangerous_mode_of_some_thing

  if enabled:
    do_something(dangerous_mode)


But I do think this use case is pretty far fetched ... so let's ignore it for now'}, {'account_id': 7642, 'date': '2013-06-13 02:26:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (6 inline comments)

why would the API for this not be __call__()
Please see my comments

For the next 2 comments, i agree with you and will add error handling here.

For the last one, let us put it in low priority for now.'}, {'account_id': 7642, 'date': '2013-06-14 08:52:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-14 08:53:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Add reload_config_files function

Add reload_config_files function for ConfigOpts instance to
reload all configuration files.

Implements blueprint cfg-reload-config-files

Change-Id: Ia4d96be170d1ddfaa70b8e467b9a19ed45dc4060

Use assertEqual() rather than assertEquals()

assertEquals() is deprecated:

  http://docs.python.org/2/library/unittest.html#deprecated-aliases

Change-Id: I9e74cb0f989854804f7bf7e89cb022925b47bf16

(1 inline comment)

I dunno about others, but I think that the quantum security group api implementation shouldn't be raising HTTP-level exceptions back to nova. I think this patch makes it extremely clear, given that we're effectively catching two possibilities (an HTTPNotFound if our implementation makes an HTTP call, or the result of a python call if otherwise).

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-29 20:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

I think it didn't make sense for me to respond inline, so pasting it again here:

"I had similar concerns and spent some time looking to find the right way to handle this.

The security_group_api raises HTTPNotFound as part of its native exceptions:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/security_groups.py#L634 https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/security_group/openstack_driver.py#L33

All of the security group api tests are based around this, raising HTTPNotFound for not found. I think this is because the api is treated as standalone, if you call it directly with a get for a security group, if it's not found, it would raise HTTPNotFound.

So I thought if nova is calling the security group api as part of a compound request (create server), it could handle the native exception from it and raise its own exception that servers.py later catches and raises HTTPBadRequest for the server create."

Perhaps security group api could be refactored to raise nova exceptions, then catch them and raise the HTTP-level exceptions in https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/security_groups.py?'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-05-30 22:34:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Yeah, I think the sec group API should not return HTTP level exceptions..  They should return nova exceptions.  If nova-api needs to report HTTP exceptions back, then you do the conversion in code under nova/api/* in the tree."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2013-06-06 03:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 04:27:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-29 01:39:01.000000000', 'message': "handle 'not found' exceptions from security group api drivers

The SecurityGroupAPI has semantics to raise 'not found'
exceptions when a security group isn't found. During a server
create request, a driver (e.g. quantum driver) may raise
HTTPNotFound and left unhandled, the create request returns
'not found'. Because server create is a compound request, in
order to return 'bad request' but keep SecurityGroupAPI
semantics intact, we can handle the 'not found' exceptions
from drivers and raise the matching nova exception in those
cases.

Fixes bug 1183347

Change-Id: I7177183154b4c41037623f443cf9958ac457a020
"}, {'created': '2013-05-29 19:55:30.000000000', 'message': "handle 'not found' exceptions from security group api drivers

The SecurityGroupAPI has semantics to raise 'not found'
exceptions when a security group isn't found. During a server
create request, a driver (e.g. quantum driver) may raise
HTTPNotFound and left unhandled, the create request returns
'not found'. Because server create is a compound request, in
order to return 'bad request' but keep SecurityGroupAPI
semantics intact, we can handle the 'not found' exceptions
from drivers and raise the matching nova exception in those
cases.

Fixes bug 1183347

Change-Id: I7177183154b4c41037623f443cf9958ac457a020
"}, {'created': '2013-06-06 03:42:17.000000000', 'message': "refactor security group api not to raise http exceptions

Fixes bug 1183347

The SecurityGroupAPI had been raising http exceptions,
resulting in a difference in behavior depending on the
driver being used: nova or quantum. The nova driver
re-raises nova exceptions by default, while the quantum
driver was raising the built-in http exceptions. Since
servers.py handles nova exceptions, in some cases the
quantum driver's http exceptions weren't being handled
and resulted in a different http return code to the
user.

This change refactors SecurityGroupAPI to raise nova
exceptions which are translated to http exceptions in
the security group wsgi extension.

Change-Id: I7177183154b4c41037623f443cf9958ac457a020
"}, {'created': '2013-06-06 17:30:47.000000000', 'message': "refactor security group api not to raise http exceptions

The SecurityGroupAPI had been raising http exceptions,
resulting in a difference in behavior depending on the
driver being used: nova or quantum. The nova driver
re-raises nova exceptions by default, while the quantum
driver was raising the built-in http exceptions. Since
servers.py handles nova exceptions, in some cases the
quantum driver's http exceptions weren't being handled
and resulted in a different http return code to the
user.

Both SecurityGroupAPI classes inherit from
NativeSecurityGroupExceptions and call its static
methods to raise exceptions.

This change refactors SecurityGroupAPI to raise nova
exceptions by modifying NativeSecurityGroupExceptions.
The nova exceptions are then translated to http
exceptions in the security group wsgi extension.

Fixes bug 1183347

Change-Id: I7177183154b4c41037623f443cf9958ac457a020

commit_message:
refactor security group api not to raise http exceptions

The SecurityGroupAPI had been raising http exceptions,
resulting in a difference in behavior depending on the
driver being used: nova or quantum. The nova driver
re-raises nova exceptions by default, while the quantum
driver was raising the built-in http exceptions. Since
servers.py handles nova exceptions, in some cases the
quantum driver's http exceptions weren't being handled
and resulted in a different http return code to the
user.

Both SecurityGroupAPI classes inherit from
NativeSecurityGroupExceptions and call its static
methods to raise exceptions.

This change refactors SecurityGroupAPI to raise nova
exceptions by modifying NativeSecurityGroupExceptions.
The nova exceptions are then translated to http
exceptions in the security group wsgi extension.

Fixes bug 1183347

Change-Id: I7177183154b4c41037623f443cf9958ac457a020

Port rescue API to v3 Part 2

This patch contains the changes required to adapt the rescue
extension and the corresponding unittest to the v3 framework

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Iaa6d0cf7708b0887512db952b1e26ccde75d24ef

commit_message:
Port rescue API to v3 Part 1

This changeset only copies the v2 files (implementation and test)
into the appropriate v3 directories unchanged. The copy as-is
will not be loaded by either the v2 or v3 extension loaders. The
second changeset will then make the changes required for it to
work as a v3 extension.

This is being tried in order to make reviewing of extension
porting easier as gerrit will display only what is actually
changed for v3 rather than entirely new files

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I8dc2b42b4ffb4618978856d5520485cd34e726d9

commit_message:
Cleanup overshadowing in test_evacuate.py

Fixes overshadowing problem of uuid in test_evacuate identified in
the v2 to v3 evacuate port but separated into a separate changeset
to fix both the v2 and v3 versions at the same time

Change-Id: If1006d86eab7198484a6d5f82a3f3f328724f4d4

Nitpick about using uuid for two things."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-08 00:41:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi David - I'd be happy to fix the shadowing issue in a separate changeset which also fixes the original V2 code. But I'd like to keep this changeset as-is because the idea behind splitting porting the V2 to V3 extensions into two changesets is to have the first one be simply an unchanged version of the current V2 code and only make changes in the second or subsequent patches. This makes it much easier for people to review changes in gerrit because the diff is much simpler. It's a way to work around the inability for git/gerrit to handle a copy and move and produce an easy to read diff in one changeset."}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-10 13:42:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-06-14 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

I know this patch only copies v2 files, but I'd like to share some points of the existing code for fixing them in v3."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-14 06:09:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Ken'ichi - I'll put together a separate patch to fix the things you've identified. I'm pretty hesitant to change them for the V2 API, so would be V3 specific."}, {'account_id': 6167, 'date': '2013-06-14 06:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree with you. It seems difficult to change V2 code for them, and V3 is a good chance to do it.

I know you are doing a lot of the great jobs for API quality.
and I will share similar points for other your patches.

Is there the other place for reporting this kind of points?
Is Gerrit the best place?'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-14 12:51:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Port evacuate API to v3 Part 1

This changeset only copies the v2 files (implementation and test)
into the appropriate v3 directories unchanged. The copy as-is
will not be loaded by either the v2 or v3 extension loaders. The
second changeset will then make the changes required for it to
work as a v3 extension.

This is being done in order to make reviewing of extension porting
easier as gerrit will display only what is actually changed for v3
rather than entirely new files

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: I2c77b445b1e7a1b63993ae86cebea9922e9d098c

commit_message:
Add RedHat support for init-quantum.

Create the network-interfaces scripts and hooks necessary to run the
init-quantum script on a RedHat based system.

Change-Id: Iad48d66a35d12c140df1398ebcb374bb822c1152

Fix various Python 2.x->3.x compat issues

Fix current git's Hacking H23x warnings via
mechanical translation to avoid the easy
Python 3.x compatibility issues.

[{'account_id': 5441, 'date': '2013-06-14 14:31:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is definitely a good thing.  But would you mind opening a bug report for it explaining the issue.  Also, I don't know if the underlying issue has been fixed yet, but there is(was?) an issue with eventlet swallowing exceptions on a greenthread switch.  So anywhere that I/O happens before re-raising it's better to use nova/openstack/common/excutils#save_and_reraise_exception.  Basically anywhere that there's logging before re-raising."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-06-14 14:57:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

A newer eventlet was released that addresses the reraise problem.  However, our requirements.txt doesn't require this latest version... so we do need to save_and_reraise() around any potential IO spots."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-06-14 14:58:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Do not raise NEW exceptions

Raising NEW exception is bad practice, because we lose TraceBack.
So all places like:

except SomeException as e:
    raise e

should be replaced by

except SomeException:
    raise

If we are doing some other actions before reraising we should
store information about exception then do all actions and then
reraise it. This is caused by eventlet bug. It lost information
about exception if it switch threads.

fixes bug 1191730

Change-Id: Ia375ecef9f16bda65d5146d14ed4b37a988abb0c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-23 01:52:47.000000000', 'message': 'python3: fix imports compatibility

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several functions
to different modules. Six provides a consistent interface
to them through the fake six.moves module.

However, the urlparse, urllib2, etc modules have been combined
into one module which Six does not support so do it the old
fashioned way.

Change-Id: I8aafb4a90af9becac2c2c6e54c12ab51ff3e355f
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
'}]
commit_message:
python3: fix imports compatibility

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several functions
to different modules. Six provides a consistent interface
to them through the fake six.moves module.

However, the urlparse, urllib2, etc modules have been combined
into one module which Six does not support so do it the old
fashioned way.

Change-Id: I8aafb4a90af9becac2c2c6e54c12ab51ff3e355f
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

the tox coverage job. However, this job wouldn't work for the devstack-gate.
We need to pass the output directory to tempest_coverage.py so
that the coverage report gets put in the logs directory. After posargs was

commit_message:
Fix tempest coverage runs

Commit 8fe6db0a changed the report generation for coverage to use
the tox coverage job. However, this job wouldn't work for the devstack-gate.
We need to pass the output directory to tempest_coverage.py so
that the coverage report gets put in the logs directory. After posargs was
added to the tox job the needed arguments can be passed to the report command.
This commit adds the needed arguments to the coverage job and reworks the if
logic to correct the behavior for the coverage flag.

Change-Id: I93bb9d91637c262e4ece6580964541c40c96eb60

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-22 23:14:02.000000000', 'message': "Fix xenstore-rm race condition

If an entry is already gone from xenstore, any other xenstore-rm will
raise.

When we make calls to nova-agent, we wait for the response in Xenstore.
After a timeout period, we attempt to remove it.  If the DomID has
changed (due to a Windows VM rebooting at the right time via sysprep,
etc)... or if the agent picked up the command and didn't respond in a
timely fashion, the removal attempt will fail.  It would be normal for
the entry to be gone in this case.

This fixes the plugin to ignore when the entry is already
deleted.

Fixes bug 1193720

Change-Id: I8585a9f147cad3c5abe531620872b475eb4128c9
"}, {'created': '2013-06-23 02:16:10.000000000', 'message': "Fix xenstore-rm race condition

If an entry is already gone from xenstore, any other xenstore-rm will
raise.

When we make calls to nova-agent, we wait for the response in Xenstore.
After a timeout period, we attempt to remove it.  If the DomID has
changed (due to a Windows VM rebooting at the right time via sysprep,
etc)... or if the agent picked up the command and didn't respond in a
timely fashion, the removal attempt will fail.  It would be normal for
the entry to be gone in this case.

This fixes the plugin to ignore when the entry is already
deleted.

Fixes bug 1193720

Change-Id: I8585a9f147cad3c5abe531620872b475eb4128c9
"}]
commit_message:
Fix xenstore-rm race condition

If an entry is already gone from xenstore, any other xenstore-rm will
raise.

When we make calls to nova-agent, we wait for the response in Xenstore.
After a timeout period, we attempt to remove it.  If the DomID has
changed (due to a Windows VM rebooting at the right time via sysprep,
etc)... or if the agent picked up the command and didn't respond in a
timely fashion, the removal attempt will fail.  It would be normal for
the entry to be gone in this case.

This fixes the plugin to ignore when the entry is already
deleted.

Fixes bug 1193720

Change-Id: I8585a9f147cad3c5abe531620872b475eb4128c9

commit_message:
corrected default value of ListOpt config options

The auto-config-generate code had a bug, fixed by
Selvakumar's code in
https://github.com/fifieldt/autogenerate-config-docs/commit/46e6e1403878e97177574ad29bc0f38ccb925e93

Patchset 2 updates the tables with the new code.

fixes bug 1192524

fixes bug 1190624

Change-Id: I238ba20b3c1f3250f85f51b56a02e54b12eb8fbc

'}, {'created': '2013-06-24 14:02:53.000000000', 'message': 'Fix minor plugin issue

Change-Id: Icc1ac7fffdb8e640bb08aeaa7c7f7d28cf33d525

commit_message:
Fix minor plugin issue

Without explicit check that "Enable Swift" config is specified by user plugin
failed with an exception. The right behaviour is to use default value for an
not specified config. In particular that affected the UI.

Change-Id: Icc1ac7fffdb8e640bb08aeaa7c7f7d28cf33d525

commit_message:
Add partial-mesh to OVS plugin with GRE tunnel

    this patch enable the partial-mesh while using GRE tunneling, so that
    endpoint will send broadcast traffic only to other endpoint that own
    the concerned network

    Implements: blueprint ovs-tunnel-partial-mesh

Change-Id: Ie9bd17303938ac5130c5e8d22602313fdb84d406

commit_message:
Quantumapi returns an empty network list

When nova retries network list and if the list is empty, quantumapi
should return a empty list instead of an empty dictionnary.

Fixes bug 1189976

Change-Id: I5b8c498a6c86e92d0de14d8de9e55722408c5669

Hi Akihiro, thanks for the review :)

As i stated in the bug report this is a minimal patch just to communicate more information about what the bug is about because i believe that "a patch is worth more than thousand words", so as soon as the bug is confirmed and that i know that what i found is truly a bug and not a mis-documentation or mis-understanding from my part, i will update this patch like you suggested and also with new (regression) test case.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-24 12:01:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix support of multiple external networks in Quantum.

Allow quantum to have more than one l3-agent per host, and change AMPQ
communication between quantum-server and l3-agents to use broadcast
messaging instead of unicast.

fixes bug: #1191729

Change-Id: I6adec0af9a725d2292c2e409140fde49e5d66ae8
'}]
commit_message:
Fix support of multiple external networks in Quantum.

Allow quantum to have more than one l3-agent per host, and change AMPQ
communication between quantum-server and l3-agents to use broadcast
messaging instead of unicast.

fixes bug: #1191729

Change-Id: I6adec0af9a725d2292c2e409140fde49e5d66ae8

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-23 22:37:38.000000000', 'message': "Add info property to the Cluster object.

* info is dict of dicts: name -> prop_name -> prop_value,
  for example, {'jobtracker': {'Web UI': 'http://...'}}
* vanilla plugin registers both jobtracker and namenode using info

Implements blueprint service-urls-info

Change-Id: I188c6e2344537a2b4bd75ff417d092a5637afd94
"}, {'created': '2013-06-23 22:46:57.000000000', 'message': "Add info property to the Cluster object.

* info is dict of dicts: name -> prop_name -> prop_value,
  for example, {'jobtracker': {'Web UI': 'http://...'}}

commit_message:
Add info property to the Cluster object.

* info is dict of dicts: name -> prop_name -> prop_value,
  for example, {'jobtracker': {'Web UI': 'http://...'}}
* vanilla plugin registers both jobtracker and namenode using info

Implements blueprint service-urls-info

Change-Id: I188c6e2344537a2b4bd75ff417d092a5637afd94

commit_message:
Tweak quotas tests to include new local-disk quota.

In other patch we create a new quota of local-disk, which contains the
root disk and ephemeral disk. Because that patch make the response of quota API
changed, so tweak these tests for that modifications.

The target patch is located in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27181/.
After it is merged, reopen these tests.

Change-Id: If93ccdc9ba367b66b74d7f051f84766c37b87815

commit_message:
Support root disk and ephemeral disk quota

Since the resource-reporter see root disk and ephemeral disk as solid stuff
"local_gb". For match the conversation, adding a new quota named 'local_gb'
to limit root disk and ephemeral disk.

Implement blueprint: root-and-ephemeral-disk-quota

Change-Id: I7adac3ee0dd907e457e961157d9ef5d538eede99

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-10 22:58:37.000000000', 'message': "Region selector enabling multi-region support.

This builds on changes in a proposed patch to
django-openstack-auth adding a region selector dropdown
at the top of both the Project and Admin dashboards if
more than one region is available in the user's service
catalog.  The user is allowed to choose from any region
available in the service catalog.

If there are more than one endpoint for a service in a
region the first in the catalog is returned.  Further
work on the blueprint will handle that complexity.

Keystone v3 catalog support is not added yet as the only
token type available in Horizon currently is in the v2
format.

Partially implements blueprint multiple-service-endpoints

Change-Id: I1ab6539c7c5f4b1ae4b1716059370e86b6ca4d2e

"}, {'created': '2013-05-22 20:36:43.000000000', 'message': "Region selector enabling multi-region support.

This patch adds a region selector dropdown
at the top of both the Project and Admin dashboards if
more than one region is available in the user's service
catalog.  The user is allowed to choose from any region
available in the service catalog. By selecting a region,
the user is limited to accessing endpoints in that
region only as long as the go through api.base.url_for

If there are more than one endpoint for a service in a
region the first in the catalog is returned.  Further
work on the blueprint will handle that complexity.

Supporting Keystone v2.0 and v3 catalog formats.

Partially implements blueprint multiple-service-endpoints

Change-Id: I1ab6539c7c5f4b1ae4b1716059370e86b6ca4d2e

commit_message:
Region selector enabling multi-region support.

This patch adds a region selector dropdown
at the top of both the Project and Admin dashboards if
more than one region is available in the user's service
catalog.  The user is allowed to choose from any region
available in the service catalog. By selecting a region,
the user is limited to accessing endpoints in that
region only as long as the go through api.base.url_for

If there are more than one endpoint for a service in a
region the first in the catalog is returned.  Further
work on the blueprint will handle that complexity.

Supporting Keystone v2.0 and v3 catalog formats.

Partially implements blueprint multiple-service-endpoints

Change-Id: I1ab6539c7c5f4b1ae4b1716059370e86b6ca4d2e

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-24 02:33:50.000000000', 'message': 'Emit alarm actions if a rule remains in ALARM state.

It looks like the original intent of this edge-triggering was to
prevent actions being emitted too frequently, causing overshoot of
scaling resources.

However this causes an issue when one scaling resource change is not
enough to bring the alarm state under the threshold.

Proper use of Period, EvaluationPeriods and Threshold should be sufficient
to prevent scaling resource overshoot.

Fixes bug: #1193970

Change-Id: I5b38eb82cd1ad568fe4af77999e9d52f9eb99328
'}]
commit_message:
Emit alarm actions if a rule remains in ALARM state.

It looks like the original intent of this edge-triggering was to
prevent actions being emitted too frequently, causing overshoot of
scaling resources.

However this causes an issue when one scaling resource change is not
enough to bring the alarm state under the threshold.

Proper use of Period, EvaluationPeriods and Threshold should be sufficient
to prevent scaling resource overshoot.

Fixes bug: #1193970

Change-Id: I5b38eb82cd1ad568fe4af77999e9d52f9eb99328

commit_message:

RAMDISK_ELEMENT is a spurious difference, to merge the code we need
only semantic difference to exist.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 16:38:55.000000000', 'message': "Change period type in alarms API to int.

Previously this was float, which looks like an over-sight,
as we will not be supporting sub-second evaluation.

Also float is a mismatch with the v2 statistics API, which
requires that the given period be an int (the alarm period
is passed to the statistics API).

Finally, the sqlalchmey schema defines the period as Integer,
so it makes no sense for the types stored mongo & mysql to
differ.

Submitting this one-liner as a separate patch, as it may be
slightly controversial because it requires that all existing
alarms stored in mongo be deleted and re-created (as we don't
have a schema migration mechnanism for mongo).

Change-Id: Id999005e4de5d77309b0a32ad582804525ec1494
"}, {'created': '2013-06-21 16:40:48.000000000', 'message': "Change period type in alarms API to int.

Previously this was float, which looks like an over-sight,
as we will not be supporting sub-second evaluation.

Also float is a mismatch with the v2 statistics API, which
requires that the given period be an int (the alarm period
is passed to the statistics API during threshold eval).

Finally, the sqlalchmey schema defines the period as Integer,
so it makes no sense for the types stored mongo & mysql to
differ.

Submitting this one-liner as a separate patch, as it may be
slightly controversial because it requires that all existing
alarms stored in mongo be deleted and re-created (as we don't
have a schema migration mechnanism for mongo).

Change-Id: Id999005e4de5d77309b0a32ad582804525ec1494
"}]
commit_message:
Change period type in alarms API to int.

Previously this was float, which looks like an over-sight,
as we will not be supporting sub-second evaluation.

Also float is a mismatch with the v2 statistics API, which
requires that the given period be an int (the alarm period
is passed to the statistics API during threshold eval).

Finally, the sqlalchmey schema defines the period as Integer,
so it makes no sense for the types stored mongo & mysql to
differ.

Submitting this one-liner as a separate patch, as it may be
slightly controversial because it requires that all existing
alarms stored in mongo be deleted and re-created (as we don't
have a schema migration mechnanism for mongo).

Change-Id: Id999005e4de5d77309b0a32ad582804525ec1494

commit_message:
make stack creation return json response

added a serializer to handle create response serialization

fixes bug #1187883

Change-Id: Ibdeb8b810d759901979becb8b29bdc337f2f5bec

Dan: Would you please explain the logic behind your most recent patch (maybe find me on irc)?  I switched from property to param for the attributes in question to prevent a user from being able to modify them (as per advice I may have misunderstood from you), as they are read-only post-creation from the quantum side.  I was under the impression that setting them as params would mean that providing them in a resource declaration would cause problems if they already existed."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

The latest patch adds an example manifest that I'll use to document how to use the new types."}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

the reason that I switched them to properties is so they would be queried when you run the command:

    puppet resource quantum_network

This also means they could be queried from another resource within the same catalog at run time if required.

also, b/c I saw they were being passed to the constructor in self.instances but not presented when I ran the above command.

The use cannot reset them, b/c I overrode the setter methods for them and raised an exception (which would only happen if you tried to update them for an existing resource)'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I would be more than happy to see people working on it. I don't have much free time to work on this review those days. That why I posted my work publicly as WIP so people can contribute.

Let me know if you have any questions. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Work In Progress'}, {'account_id': 7156, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

"Networks are updated/deleted by name in this patch, which means a network whose name that is duplicated will be impossible to manage."

I know about this limitation. It is the same with Glance images.

We should explain this limitation to the end user somehow. Puppet has to rely on a unique key to manage a ressource and we don't really have one, except the name. We can't rely on the UUID because we don't know it in advance.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-24 06:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-02-25 15:42:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

Looks good to me, but I don't have much experience with Keystone.

One minor question inline."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-02-25 16:29:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

The env_identity is from _keystone_identity() at line 117. If the req.env doesn't contain enough user/tenant info. The return value of env_identity('tenant') and env_identity will be (None, None). So that before defualt empty string is not necessary here"}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-02-25 16:35:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Btw, does the "tenant_name:*" is good acl for allowing all users in that tenant?
This has be mentioned https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1075362'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-03-01 15:13:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Is there use cases for this or is it just for consitenties? I am not sure I understand Dan's argument in the bug report that he need it to be able to not have to keep names in ACL."}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-01 15:23:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Can you add a little more comments to describe the purpose
of this patch? With this patch, if a system is down level,
like keystone is down level, but the middle ware used in
swift is not, or the other way around, will this still work?
can there be any test cases added to verify this?"}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-02 04:13:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

1. The bug #1020709 and #1075362 talk different things but locate in same codes, so I mentioned the tenant_name:* because for the same purpose I can fix two bugs in one patch. (of course, we should talk first)

2. The purpose of this patch is to keep readability for user. When setting ACL, user will prefer tenant name and user name than both ids. We already allow tenant_name:user, so allowing tenant_name:user_name and tenant_id:user_name is also friendly to swift users. In bug #1075362, Daniel prefers tenant_name:* is allowed in ACL, but at the same time, *:user_name is already allowed. So should tenant:* is a good usage? That's my another question.

3. The cases are sample. Using ACL, deploying sample data(https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/tools/sample_data.sh), removing ADMIN role of nova, and using swift user to try "xxxxxxx_tenant_id:nova", "service:nova", and now user nova could access service(tenant) data.

4. To litong01, this part ACL is supported by autotoken middleware which located in keystone and keystoneclient. The autotoken is a basic concept in openstack authorization. It's hard to crash by "downlevel"

5. Test cases:
5.1 build swift+keystone (with both *client)
5.2 use https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/tools/sample_data.sh to deploy data.
5.3 remove ADMIN role of nova
5.4 try any access to service(tenant) by nova will be disallowed.
5.5 try ACL"xxxxx_tenant_id:nova" or "service:nova" will make the access ok.

6. For another question you maybe ask further. In keystoneauth middleware, I catch data "user name" from env. Does it stable? My answer is yes, this user name is as stable as tenant name in our current usage.(checking this please: https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/middleware/auth_token.py) Further, if any unexpected errors happened, some exception will be catched or not in keystone, not swift.

Any question more?'}, {'account_id': 2860, 'date': '2013-03-04 03:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Kun Huang, What I was asking is that when you have mismatch 
keystone and keystone middleware, what will happen? You were saying 'it is hard to crash "Downlevel"' does not really
make much sense to me. what do you really mean by that? Hard
to crash does mean it still crashes, right? You also refer
something like autotoken, do you actually mean authtoken?

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-04 05:45:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi, litong01
Sorry for misunderstanding your "Downlevel" and my misspelling of authtoken.
I think now you want me to be clear about what will happen when ANYHING unexpected occurred.
The principle of defense programming is to give proper choice to any unexpected things, like catching it and re-processing, hiding it in main output, or showing it as welcome, as debug-able as we can.
I have read the codes, and have my own understanding about defensing work of original authors. And during adding my own codes, I choose to follow original style.

If you HAVE READ the codes, you should know keystoneauth's defense work depends on its debug level logs. In authorize(), each branch in code flow has been record by log. To follow this style, it's especially irresponsible to add try-except to your own codes without thinking about context more.

So, what I have done is to understand context around that target codes, evaluate the risk, and give my choice.

If you're not familiar with keystone/keystoneclient/authtoken, I give my understanding.
authtoken is basic concept of keystone, keystone is core authorizing function in openstack. If keystone doesn't work, what should swift do is giving a debug-able output. Now swift is good at this work.

authtoken provide many stable data in "env", such as user_id, tenant_id, tenant_name. user_name is also one of them which is needed in my patch. (why stable? http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystone/api_curl_examples.html#get-tokens-token-id)

Current workflow will not drive to crash. But if you set a trace in codes and change a complicated object to a string in runtime, keystone'll crash, and swift cannot response an expected result. As a result, I think user_name in env is at very very low level risk, so I choose to get it content without any try-except and log.warning.

That's my choice.'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-08 19:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-08 19:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-swift-pep8/1811 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-swift-docs/1649 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-swift-python26/1897 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-swift-python27/1899 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/7802 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/12936 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/5/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/7518 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-08 20:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Here are some use cases or test cases:
1. build swift with keystone
2. deploy keystone data: using any correct user/role/tenant is ok; for easy, use this, https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/tools/sample_data.sh; if you use this script, remember removing admin role of nova user since we will use nova later
3. test all schemes: now we have admin=>swift,none_admin=>nova, tenant=>service; let us use swift set ACL to allow nova access data.
4. build any data, containers or objects in account:service
5. test:
run: swift post XXcontainer -m "service:nova";use nova to run: swift stat XXcontainer
If works, it will return data in XXcontainer'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-21 20:28:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

In my very limited understanding of the Keystone world, there are two things: tenants (groups of users? mysterious abstract groups of stuff? both?) and users, and ACLs are specified in the form "#{tenant}:#{user}".

Also, it seems to me that the tenant and user fields can each take on one of three values: the ID of the thing, the name of the thing, or a wildcard ("*").

GIven that, I'd think that there'd actually be 9 distinct forms to handle, not just 6. Specifically, we'd have:

    tenant_id:user_id
    tenant_id:user_name
    tenant_id:*
    tenant_name:user_id
    tenant_name:user_name
    tenant_name:*
    *:user_id
    *:user_name
    *:*

Does that make sense, or am I missing something?'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-23 14:46:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

That is whtat I worried about. The current only support 3 forms. I didn't find out any reason about that in documents or comments. If no, I agree with supporting all 9 forms here."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-25 23:50:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

The 3 forms mentioned date all the way back to commit afa4f70, which is the import of the middleware from keystone.

Over in keystone's repository, it looks like commit 30654a6 took that middleware from being tenant_name/* only to tenant_id/tenant_name/* in the first position.

Prior to that, f3af691 looks like it switched out tenant_id/* for tenant_name/*, but it's hard for me to be sure.

Before *that*, we have commit 6c5c964, which introduces the ACL stuff into the middleware for the first time.

Going back just a little bit further, we have the extinction of the dinosaurs.

It looks to me like this stuff is all more than a year old, and I think Keystone underwent a nearly-complete rewrite in that year, as well as sprouting an entirely new API version. I wouldn't worry about backwards compatibility, and I'd just fix it to include all 9 cases for consistency."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-26 03:12:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks for those details. I'll adjust my commit"}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-26 05:23:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-03-26 06:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build succeeded.

'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-26 09:38:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/7/check/gate-swift-pep8/1975 : SUCCESS

- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/10476 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/16021 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/22820/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/10192 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-26 17:08:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good to me.

If you feel like improving this a little further, I have one further suggestion, though it's up to you whether or not to implement it.

Currently, _authorize_cross_tenant() returns True/False, and then its caller up in authorize() logs just that the request is authorized.

What if _authorize_cross_tenant() returned either the matching ACL or None? Then the log message could not only say that the request is authorized, but could also say which ACL allowed the request. I feel like that might be helpful to people trying to debug their auth stuff.

Like I said, it's not required, but it would be nice to have."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-26 21:40:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

A little question: if there're two tenant:user format matched in roles, what should be our expected log msg?

I got some feedback from keystone mail list which said that's basically up to the identity driver in use. If with SQL driver and database is case sensitive, the keystone will be as well.
I also noticed that a related patch (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/24824/) was abandoned because keystone back ported it."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-03-29 21:32:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Got some clarification on the mailing list: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2013-March/007072.html

The short answer is that Keystone identity stuff (tenants, roles, usernames, etc.) are not case sensitive and MUST NOT* be compared in a case-insensitive way.

I think the bit about the SQL driver doesn't matter for purposes of comparison. That is, "BOB != Bob" at all times, but depending on Keystone's SQL backend, you may not be able to have users BOB and Bob at the same time.

* see RFC 2119'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-03-31 06:48:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Let's not merge this until after the meeting."}, {'account_id': 4108, 'date': '2013-06-04 10:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

My 2 cents, just on this issue of compatibility of API to the middlewares:

We are risking to become incapacitated if we will start assuming we cant change anything that any existing code may rely on. 

Anyone that have code extending Swift needs to keep up with the changes we are making to Swift. We need to have a good way of communicating and highlighting such changes such that extensions will be aligned by their respective authors. This is Python where every function and variable can theoretically be monkey-patched by some extension out there. 

Client API should in my eyes be the only exception.

Staff like Auth APIs and the DiskFile API that we plan to provide should be changeable, subject to proper documentation of the changes.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-04 12:47:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

re compat: A pretty good process is to support both old and new for a release and then remove the old the next release after that, giving external developers time to react. Otherwise everyone is scrambling just after release day trying to fix things. There are some things that can't be done both ways though; for those, you've just got to make the change and try to get the word out (mailing lists, w/e) before the release is final. Remember that not all external devs follow Swift dev day-to-day."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-04 16:39:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

nice following up

As what gholt said, if I want keep both in current release, it should be implemented like:

user = 'user_name';user['id'] = 'user_id';user['name] = 'user_name'

It is not totally impossible but maybe leave more complicated codes here (we have to use a custom object instead of basic dict). Or any more implementation?

But at first of all, I don't think this env['keystone.identity'] break compatibility too much. As new concept like group involved in keystone, developers have to update their auth-related middleware based on their codes version. So back compatibility is not such a good reason in this case in my mind."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

^^ strongly implies that something like the functionality in this patch is possible, but seems to suggest a different literal string to represent the tenant_id:* case.

Also, as an additional use case, https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1155389'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-04 17:47:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Mark, it should be documented but seems in keystone part only.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-06-05 15:21:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

kun: before someone writting a middleware would have to get user :

user = req.environ['keystone.identity']['user']

this patch breaks it"}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-05 15:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

chmouel: yes, it does. But I agree with gholt more, the best way is to keep new and old in current release and to give up old in next release. However, it is a little contradictory.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-05 17:25:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Nah, that's not contradictory.

You've got a few requirements: 

* KeystoneAuth.authorize() must have access to the tenant id/name and the user id/name in order to make its decision
* the value in env['keystone.identity'] must not change
* the callable placed in env['swift.authorize'] must take a request as its one and only argument

So then the question is: why is keystone.identity in the environment at all? In the code on master, it's used by KeystoneAuth.__call__ to make the tenant id/name and the user name available to KeystoneAuth.authorize.

However, if you notice that KeystoneAuth.__call__ is also responsible for setting env['swift.authorize'], you'll see that there's a way to give the user id to KeystoneAuth.authorize without altering the value in env['keystone.identity'] at all. In fact, it removes any need for authorize() to look in the environment at all.

Hint: it starts with "f", and ends with "unctools.partial".'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-05 18:32:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Do you mean something like this?
env['swift.authorize'] = partial(self.authorize, user_id=xxx) and def self.authorize(self, req, **kwargs):

I'm sorry I don't like it at all. I think another requirement is that we must keep codes clean and understandable. If we leaves such codes in master, the following coders must doubt the purpose of such things, just like we doubt why current keystone.identity doesn't contain user id.

The contradictory thing in my mind is this. the env['keystone.identity'] is a normal dict not a custom object which we could easily modify a member on it.

If you don't think using partial will confuse others, please find an example like this in swift or other sub-projects in OpenStack.

BTW, is any other developer want to know identity information, the first choice is not env['keystone.identity'], but the env['HTTP_X_USER_ID']. The downstream middleware after keystoneauth can't get any promise env['keystone.identity'] never change a little. But such header is not, if exists, it must be the correct value you need."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-05 20:46:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Pretty much, that's what I meant. I'd pass the whole identity in, not just the user id, so something like:

    # compatibility only; remove after the Icehouse release
    env['keystone.identity'] = make_some_legacy_thingy_from(identity)

    env['swift.authorize'] = functools.partial(self.authorize, identity=identity)

    def authorize(self, req, identity):
        # stuff

That way you don't have pieces of the identity coming in via two different methods; it's all in the "identity" argument, and the stuff in env['keystone.identity'] is there only for backwards-compatibility reasons.

As for understandability, functools is in the Python standard library. It's not like it's some crazy thing that Swift invented, or some seldom-used wacky library on PyPi. There's an argument to be made for not using esoteric libraries, but I do not think that "esoteric" is a term that can be applied to the Python standard library.

(Also, there's a couple uses of functools.partial already in Swift, and a quick "git grep functools.partial" in Nova shows 9 hits. I don't find social proof to be particularly useful in this case, but since you do, here's some social proof for you.)'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-06 02:53:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

sam
I think we need understandability of using some tricks like partial to keep compatibility, not only partial itself. And watching functools.partial in nova, do you know which one is used to keep compat and will be deleted later? So I prefer a simpler way.

Maybe you could say we can add some comments and delete the old way later, but no one could promise the delete. Just like this: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/middleware/keystoneauth.py#L223

I agree with gholt, but I prefer do nothing with that compatibility here. One reason I can't find a simple way to promise the old style will be deleted in time. Another is if people use codes in master branch, they have responsibility to fix their codes for new feature. Not only the user_id issue we talk about, some new concept in keystone or deprecated ones would let people to update their own codes."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-06 04:01:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

The example commit you reference, by the way, was just deprecated last release. Though I agree we probably forget to remove old stuff, that wasn't a good example (yet).

If you're really worried about forgetting, file a Launchpad bug, do the code work now, push it to Gerrit, and make yourself a calendar reminder. :)

I think Sam said it'd be discussed and decided at the Swift Team Meeting next week (which is open to all) whether knowingly breaking something in a single release or deprecating one release and breaking the next is the way to go. Seems an obvious choice to me, but I guess by this discussion it's not such an obvious choice group-wide."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-06 04:15:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

ok, gholt, let's talk a few days later"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-06 18:13:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The more I think about this, the less I like changing what's in the WSGI environment.

At first, I didn't think anything of changing env['keystone.identity'] since nothing else in Swift cared, and I didn't know about Chmouel's middleware.

Then, I thought that the better ACLs and backwards compatibility were at odds, and we'd either have to give one up or end up with horribly ugly code in Swift to avoid breaking some external middleware that I've never heard of.

Now, though, we've found a way to deal with the parsed keystone identity that not only maintains backwards compatibility, but also keeps the data entirely internal to keystoneauth, thereby removing any concerns about future compatibility too. I can't actually think of any way in which changing env['keystone.identity'] is better than keeping it out of the environment entirely.

As for which uses of functools.partial in Nova are used for backwards compatibility: I neither know nor care. Initially, I claimed that functools.partial was an entirely understandable thing to use, and you asked for evidence of that claim, specifically in the form of users in other  OpenStack projects. Those have been provided. Don't move the goalposts."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-07 03:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I agree with "keep both better ACLs and backwards compatibility"

About "functools.partial was an entirely understandable thing", I prefer trust you than argue it. You're more experienced.

Another talks about keeping backwards compatibility, what do you think about this implementation:

change https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/middleware/keystoneauth.py#L164 into:

env_identity = self._keystone_new_identity(environ) # including user_id here.

My reason: self.authorize just care its own identity, so I give it a new one. And I don't change env['keystone.identity'] and leave it other middleware.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-07 03:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Sounds like a good plan.'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-07 03:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Thanks

Below two bug reports talk about one thing.
Current keystoneauth ACL supports as:

tenant_name:*               no
*:user_name                 ok
tenant_name:user_name       no
tenant_id:user_name         no
tenant_name:user_id         ok
tenant_id:user_id           ok

This patch will make all of above work fine.
Applying (tenant/user)name could let user put or get their data in a
more readable way. The tenant_name:* and *:user_name is suitable for
many usage.

Fixes: bug #1020709
Fixes: bug #1075362

commit_message:
Improve swift's keystoneauth ACL support

Below three bug reports talk about one thing.
Current keystoneauth ACL supports as:

tenant_name:user_id         ok
tenant_name:user_name       no
tenant_name:*               no
tenant_id:user_id           ok
tenant_id:user_name         no
tenant_id:*                 no
*:user_id                   ok
*:user_name                 no
*:*                         no

This patch will make all of above work fine.
Applying (tenant/user)name could let user put or get their data in a
more readable way. The tenant_name:* and *:user_name is suitable for
many usage.

note: to keep compatibility here add a new keystone.identity just for
authorize() itself and leave env['keystone.identity'] to other
middlerwares.

Fixes: bug #1020709
Fixes: bug #1075362
Fixes: bug #1155389
Change-Id: I9354dedaad875117f6a9072c67e9ecf69bfca77e

Django object id is usually a int while lookup is an unicode string.

commit_message:
Make get_object_by_id() work for most Django objects.

Django object id is usually a int while lookup is an unicode string.
It works for Openstack but other not Django objects.

This patch makes other standard Django apps reusing Horizon easier.

Change-Id: I3f2ccad89023545311839c5b2814ec557a97de8a

commit_message:
mongodb: fix limit value not being an integer

PyMongo actually wants an integer and not None.
It seems that was hidden by MIM.

Change-Id: Ia3583018f841ca0387a467cd9f24c13124ab4141

If you make a range request for a manifest object, then the proxy can
retrieve more data than it actually needs from the object server. It
sends the right bytes to the client, and then spends a bunch of time
reading and discarding bytes it doesn't need.

Example:

   file start  	       	       	       	       	       file end
       |	range start	  range end		  |
       v	     v         	       v       	       	  v
       [--------------------------------------------------]

The proxy would send a request to the object server with "Range:
bytes=${range start}-", and so the object server responds with all the
bytes from range start to file end. This needlessly transfers all the
bytes from range end to file end, as none of those are sent to the
client.

This commit fixes the sent Range header to only request the bytes
needed.

Change-Id: Ie8d4ee2c5e67c08795ac2d39d1df7d11856621a9
'}]
commit_message:
Stop getting useless bytes on manifest Range requests.

If you make a range request for a manifest object, then the proxy can
retrieve more data than it actually needs from the object server. It
sends the right bytes to the client, and then spends a bunch of time
reading and discarding bytes it doesn't need.

Example:

   file start  	       	       	       	       	       file end
       |	range start	  range end		  |
       v	     v         	       v       	       	  v
       [--------------------------------------------------]

The proxy would send a request to the object server with "Range:
bytes=${range start}-", and so the object server responds with all the
bytes from range start to file end. This needlessly transfers all the
bytes from range end to file end, as none of those are sent to the
client.

This commit fixes the sent Range header to only request the bytes
needed.

Change-Id: Ie8d4ee2c5e67c08795ac2d39d1df7d11856621a9

[{'created': '2013-06-17 10:11:37.000000000', 'message': "Python-2.6 compatibility for tests/test_keyring.py

TestCase.setUpClass() and unittest.SkipTest are features added in 2.7.
Calling super(KeyringTest, cls).setUpClass() could have never worked
since tests.utils.TestCase doesn't implement that (class) method.

Change-Id: Ifbb0465be24fd13ad68d52c0d7fa4c5090d0f694
"}]
commit_message:
Python-2.6 compatibility for tests/test_keyring.py

TestCase.setUpClass() and unittest.SkipTest are features added in 2.7.
Calling super(KeyringTest, cls).setUpClass() could have never worked
since tests.utils.TestCase doesn't implement that (class) method.

Change-Id: Ifbb0465be24fd13ad68d52c0d7fa4c5090d0f694

Change-Id: I2b3c7d040476c451243ef3cabaf877c5f82bab03

commit_message:
Clarify behavior of trust expirations

Specifically, it wasn't clear that no `expires_at` meant the trust
lasted indefinitely.

Change-Id: I2b3c7d040476c451243ef3cabaf877c5f82bab03

We still need this code in the v1 and v2 version of the cinderclient as the v1 client is instantiated by default. If the code was only in v2 and a user of cinder was to install the python client and run help, they wouldn't see the transfer commands."}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2013-05-31 21:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I'm a bit mixed here;

First the code looks and works fine so that part, "Nice work"

The commit message could be fixed up as Rushi points out, but more importantly is the point made by Rushi about continuing to duplicate new features in V1 and V2.  I would at some point like to stop duplicating everything in both versions of the API.  I can be swayed depending on input from others with the SP perspective, but it seems like starting in H everything should be set/expected to use V2.

The -1 is just to get thoughts on this and make sure the points made by Rushi aren't lost.  The code itself works quite well and looks good.'}, {'account_id': 951, 'date': '2013-06-05 08:45:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-05 08:45:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Implements support migration for volume transfer

Implements support for the volume transfer api added to cinder in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/29227

Change-Id: Idbcdfdd3ef76a8c516e08d1cf351d549254bc8c0

[{'created': '2013-06-21 22:03:29.000000000', 'message': 'Adds create_from_volume test cases

  For tests.test_volumes,
  added 3 test cases:
     create_from_volume
     create_from_volume_with_glance_metadata
     create_from_volume_failed_on_cloning
  refactored an internal api:
     _create_volume_from_image

  The reason not to test a non-exist volume as source_vol is
  the uplayer(volume api) has already checked and ensured the
  source_vol exists

Change-Id: I9c345bc29cae31f1a22236a4849f13d7289ea49e
'}]
commit_message:
Adds create_from_volume test cases

  For tests.test_volumes,
  added 3 test cases:
     create_from_volume
     create_from_volume_with_glance_metadata
     create_from_volume_failed_on_cloning
  refactored an internal api:
     _create_volume_from_image

  The reason not to test a non-exist volume as source_vol is
  the uplayer(volume api) has already checked and ensured the
  source_vol exists

Change-Id: I9c345bc29cae31f1a22236a4849f13d7289ea49e

commit_message:
Clean up some remnants of StaticWeb's and TempURL's custom caching.

As of e499b91, these config values and functions are unused in StaticWeb.

As of 2e155e5, the comment in TempURL is false.

Change-Id: I75b631ece8a9a6075c406765361629c549c449f6

[{'created': '2013-06-21 13:21:05.000000000', 'message': 'NetApp:iSCSI drivers reserved percent need to change to 0.

The iscsi drivers reserved percent is 100 as of now. This needs
to be changed to 0 for default values. It needs to be corrected
so that filter scheduler does not discard netapp backend.

bug 1182015

Change-Id: Id80584e5d478c83de97735706994206e024f8bf6
'}]
commit_message:
NetApp:iSCSI drivers reserved percent need to change to 0.

The iscsi drivers reserved percent is 100 as of now. This needs
to be changed to 0 for default values. It needs to be corrected
so that filter scheduler does not discard netapp backend.

bug 1182015

Change-Id: Id80584e5d478c83de97735706994206e024f8bf6

commit_message:
Remove single-version-externally-managed in setup.cfg

The single-version-externally-managed flag is no longer
a config option in pbr, it is now the default behaviour
in normal setuptools.

Change-Id: I5173d78680afca534b28cefa155636d9d695b1d9

messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-07 23:26:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/32213/1/check/gate-noop/2411 : SUCCESS in 0s
'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-06-08 00:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2013-06-08 07:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I have mixed feelings on this. Making a task itself a small workflow via this new yield syntax may help it become easier to adopt existing code by splattering yields every so often but I am not sure if thats a good goal to have. It would almost seem better just to correctly re/structure the spider code in the first place instead of partially structuring it with yield splattering.

The yield splattering also gets into the area of coroutines which openstack already has eventlet to accomplish (and heat has something else that is eventlet+yield).'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-23 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-23 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

[{'created': '2013-06-07 23:26:08.000000000', 'message': 'Allow for multi-phase tasks.

Allow for tasks to be multi-phase or single-phase
and accommodate tracking the task if it is either
type. If a single task is multi-phase then it must
operate slightly differently as well as squash
its phases into a single result (if applicable).

blueprint multi-phase-task

Change-Id: I27b87f6d925fe07a4e3233b4ec256df2d9868c40
'}]
commit_message:
Allow for multi-phase tasks.

Allow for tasks to be multi-phase or single-phase
and accommodate tracking the task if it is either
type. If a single task is multi-phase then it must
operate slightly differently as well as squash
its phases into a single result (if applicable).

blueprint multi-phase-task

Change-Id: I27b87f6d925fe07a4e3233b4ec256df2d9868c40

find the keys directory.

'}, {'account_id': 5805, 'date': '2013-06-22 15:17:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

is there a bug we can link this to?"}, {'account_id': 4919, 'date': '2013-06-22 16:55:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If i don't add the h302 ignore, when you run flake8, there are two h302 import only modules errors and in many condition it's convenient for us to import objects rather than modules. So i choose to ignore this problem."}, {'account_id': 5805, 'date': '2013-06-22 18:17:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree, but I think we should file a bug to track why we are doing it.'}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2013-06-22 18:26:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not merge

JimJiang, we should not be ignoring this HACKING check, which is part of openstack standards.

If there are specific objects which we frequently need to import, it is possible to add exceptions. See how Nova allows importing objects from the db/api module. That said, I would want to see a good explanation for why we cant import a module.'}, {'account_id': 4919, 'date': '2013-06-23 05:35:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Devananda is right, i should not ignore the standard HACKING standards made by openstack.'}]

subject: Loosen constraints on Swift status codes.
messages:
[{'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-19 19:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-19 19:20:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2013-06-19 19:42:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Ok, this is a -1 because this will accept *any* response code in 200 including completely invalid ones not in http. (like 286 for example)  If swift's api really will return different response codes for the same operation success then list them explicitly.

My bigger concern is over the assertion that the Swift API doesn't commit to having a set status code return. I'm not really familiar with the swift api so I can't really say anything about this statement. But, if the status code isn't static for an operation then why haven't we had random swift failures in the gate? We want tempest to warn us if the api status codes change so that we don't inadvertently end up breaking someone's client who expects a certain status code. I would -2 a change like this if it was for another project's api, but since I'm not familiar with swift I'll hold off."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-19 20:10:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures
