- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/24727 : FAILURE in 49m 55s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/24433 : FAILURE in 40m 18s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/32218 : FAILURE in 20m 22s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/1921 : FAILURE in 49m 04s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-19 22:09:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Fair point about status codes outside of HTTP. I will tighten those lists up a bit.

As for particular status codes, let's assume for a moment that Swift only promises a successful response code, but does not commit to, say, a 204.

Let's consider the account HEAD request (the others are similar). It is the case that Swift master currently returns a 204 for an account HEAD request in all cases. However, the API spec does not promise a 204; it only promises 2xx. The fact that it's a 204 on master is an implementation detail, not a promise.

Now, let's say that a developer makes a change to Swift, and as a side effect, account HEAD requests might sometimes return 200, sometimes 204, and sometimes 205. Those are all 2xx, so it should be okay, but that change won't pass Tempest because Tempest wants 204 and nothing else. Seems to me that Tempest should allow what the API says, not what Swift happens to return today.


For reference, here's the doc for the Get Account Metadata (account HEAD) request in Swift: <http://docs.openstack.org/api/openstack-object-storage/1.0/content/retrieve-account-metadata.html>. Any 2xx status code indicates success, but Tempest will only take 204.

Swift has changed stuff like this before, too. It used to be that an object GET with "Range: bytes=0-10,50-60" would return 200 since multiple ranges weren't supported. Now it's a 206 with the specified ranges. That could have broken any client that was expecting a 200 there, but since it's all within the bounds of HTTP and the Swift API spec, the change was merged. I see this patch set as enabling similar changes.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-19 22:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-19 22:59:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-19 23:49:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/check/gate-tempest-pep8/3806 : SUCCESS in 1m 23s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/check/gate-tempest-docs/355 : SUCCESS in 1m 22s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/24802 : SUCCESS in 38m 06s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/24508 : SUCCESS in 50m 26s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/32298 : SUCCESS in 16m 14s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum-full/1929 : FAILURE in 40m 31s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-20 00:13:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

honestly, that's a terrible API definition (or lack there of). It also means that changes in API calls that would break people's code in the wild, because they were expecting back what the swift api points were actually returning, would fail.

I think I'd rather just remove all the swift tests that hit interfaces that don't commit to return codes rather than provide blanket ranges."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-20 00:38:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

If that's what you guys want to do, I can remove those tests.

Should I do that as a separate, competing patch to this one so people can compare the two, or just rewrite this patch?"}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-06-20 01:59:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I really don't understand this logic. If the return code for a specific API version can be changed at the whim of a developer, then an application cannot take any action based on what code is returned because doing so could cause the application to break in the future. In that case, who cares what the return code is and what would be the point of changing it?

As far as I know, all the other projects are following the API stability guidelines at https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Governance/Approved/APIStability which state that a success return code should not be changed for a given API version."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-20 18:23:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The way I see it, Tempest is here to ensure that projects stay within the bounds of their APIs.

Swift's API allows any 2xx status code to indicate success for most operations.

Tempest enforces specific status codes, like 204 or 201, which Swift's API does not specify.

Therefore, Tempest should change so that it does not enforce extra restrictions on Swift.


I think the proposed change here is one way to go about doing this, and it still checks that operations succeed. Sean Dague said he'd prefer to remove all the Swift tests; I'd rather not go that way since tests for 2xx still catch totally-broken code that people submit to Swift, but if that's what the Tempest team decides is right, then I'll write a patch that does so."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-20 22:21:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'd like to see if there are any other opinions on the mailing list. I'm removing my -1 at this point, because I'm kind of neutral. The fact that the Swift API predates OpenStack gives this approach some credence.

Though before we remove this, are we sure that swift actually can generate any of these other codes being tested for? One of the things that tempest was being considered for is compatibility testing, and opening it up so that it passes, but actually returns differently on different vendor implementations worries me."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-20 22:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-06-21 13:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Sam, I think we are talking past each other. The API stability doc does not address this case because we did not know there were any APIs that did not specify some set of return codes. So I am not opposed to this change on those grounds. However, I still don't see why you would want to change the success return codes in such an api because the client cannot reliably act on the value. All changing the return code can do is break an application that looked at the return value. Perhaps that application is "bad", but why do we want to break it? What is the value to anybody in changing an undefined return success code of an old api that has been in use for years?'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-21 21:58:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@David Kranz: Changing return codes can do more than just break old clients; it can fix things! Swift serves data over HTTP, and not everything that talks to Swift is a custom-written Swift-only client; you can point all sorts of HTTP-speaking things at it.

For example, in Swift right now, a container HEAD always returns 204, even though a container GET might return 200 with a nonempty body.

Now, RFC 2616 section 9.4 says "The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST NOT return a message-body in the response." Thus, the status codes for GET and HEAD of the same resource have to match. Swift doesn't always do that, so it's not living up to the HTTP 1.1 standard in this case.

Even more specifically, there are some Varnish configurations where that disparity breaks the caching of container listings, causing a GET to go all the way to the origin server (Swift) every time. Throw StaticWeb in there, and it can turn into a giant mess.

I'm working on trying to fix that mess, and Tempest won't let me because it's requiring a 204 from Swift where it oughtn't.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-22 00:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-22 04:55:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

LGTM.

BTW RFC 2616 strong etag: Is there a way with swift to automatically use more than just the entity-body for strong etag generation (I mean the entity-headers)?'}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2013-06-23 02:43:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Approved

I'm approving this because it is not my job to try to force swift to comply with the clear intent of the API stability statement that was approved by by the technical committee. The point of api stability is that we do not break applications in order to make minor improvements to apis. We do that in the next api version. Every other project is following that policy as far as I know."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-23 02:43:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Starting gate jobs.
http://status.openstack.org/zuul/'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-23 03:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-23 03:33:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/gate/gate-tempest-pep8/3856 : SUCCESS in 1m 28s
- http://logs.openstack.org/33689/4/gate/gate-tempest-docs/405 : SUCCESS in 1m 28s

commit_message:
Loosen constraints on Swift status codes.

The Swift API only commits to returning a 2xx status code to indicate
success for most operations (e.g. list containers, get account
metadata, etc.), but Tempest was looking for particular ones (e.g. 204
or 200). This change loosens those checks to accept any 2xx status
code defined in RFC 2616.

Tests for operations where the API docs *do* specify particular status
codes, like "Create Container", have been left untouched.

Change-Id: I3ba91cb915e79700124172051d50deff9bc0601b

"}, {'created': '2013-06-22 16:27:26.000000000', 'message': 'Use userdata instead of files for VM key-pair.

userdata script is supported by cloud-init package.

Fixes: bug #1193652

commit_message:
Use userdata instead of files for VM key-pair.

userdata script is supported by cloud-init package.
From now on Savanna expects images with cloud-init preinstalled.

Change-Id: Icfb34d79d22bfa5b8d682a10b42c81312ef5de8a
Fixes: bug #1193652

'}, {'account_id': 4395, 'date': '2013-06-07 04:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-07 13:29:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-07 15:09:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I still don't see anything here that waits for the de-allocation thread to complete (as per Chris's and my earlier comments).  

Just logging the error isn't enough I think, the current behavior is to leave the instance in place so that a further delete can be attempted.
  
With this new behavior the the un-deallocated network will just be left hanging there un-referenced, and we don't have any garbage colletcion which will clean up. 
 If the network deallcoation fails then the instance wi"}, {'account_id': 7531, 'date': '2013-06-10 18:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

So, would leaving the instance in "error" after the deallocation fails be enough?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-11 15:05:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Phil, any response to Kashi's question?"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-11 19:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Er, s/Kashi/Sridevi/

Phil, still waiting for a response from you…'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-12 15:35:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

With no response from Phil, I have to assume that his objection is no longer valid.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-13 19:35:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Sorry, been away.

I think you still have a race issue in here, trying to set the instance to error in thread that you've spawned won't work as far as I can see, because the original thread will have  deleted it in the meantime.

Consider this sequence:

 terminate_instance()
   _delete_instance()
      _shutdown_instance()
          _deallocate_network()         - Starts the thread to clean up the network
      _instance_update(vm_state=DELETED)
      conductor_api.instance_destroy()  - Now the instance is deleted in the DB

At this point the network thread could still be running, and if it hits an error it can't set the state.

What's missing (that the async alloc code has) is some way of waiting for the network thread to complete and report its status *before* setting the state to DELETED (otherwise you have another race condition around setting the state.

Given that this wait will need to come pretty much after you've started the thread in _shutdown_instance() I'm wondering if there really is any performance advantage in doing the deallocate as an async operation.  Just because the alloc benfits from being async (because there is a lot else to do in setting up the instance) it doesn't follow that the dealloc has to also be async.   I'm wondering if this additional complexity is really a net gain at all."}, {'account_id': 7531, 'date': '2013-06-14 14:50:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

The gain is that, when a build is rescheduled after an error, the clean up will happen faster, thus reducing the total build time.

When an instance is 'deleted', we do not knock the record off, instead, just change the status to "deleted" and mark the "deleted" flag to 1.
Case1. the thread that is executing _deallocate_network() puts it to "error". But the main thread continues and overrides the status to "deleted"
	This can be prevented by having a check before updating the status and not update if the status of the instance is "error"
Case2. the main thread finishes first and marks the instance to "deleted" and the deallocate thread fails and marks it to error.
       I don't see any issues with this case.

Do you have any concerns around this approach?

Also, now that I think about it, putting the instance to "error" when the deallocation of network fails, may not the right thing to do.
What if we maintain the failures in a different table. Please let me know your thoughts on it.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-14 17:40:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Hi Sridevi,

Sorry, I still don't get this argument.  There are two conditions that have to be met, and as far as I can see the current code doesn't guarantee either:

1) When the thread that spawned the deallocation finishes, the deallocatiion thread needs to have finished as well.   Handing back control of the request to say the scheduler, which may cause another allocation to run on another node somewhere while the original deallocation is still running is a race condition just waiting to happen

2) If the deallocation fails during a user initiated delete then the instance needs to remain un-deleted and in an error state so that the user will re-run the deletion and hopefully clear up whatever made the deallcoation fail.   It no value putting a deleted instance record into an error state as the user won't see it and can#t act on it, and so you'll end up with some network resource not properly deallocated.

Both of these conditions are met in the current non-async code, and I'm looking to make sure that any performance optimizaion doesn't break them. 

Chris Behrens (on who's work this change is based) pretty much noted the same thing his review comments for patch set 7 when he said "I think that wherever _deallocate_network() is called, you should then do a gt.wait() before returning."

I don't think your assumption that the clean-up will happen faster if a build is rescheduled after an error by leaving the de-allocation thread running is safe - and if you have to wait for it to finish then really I don't see a gain in time.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-06-14 18:14:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Phil: To be fair, I saw an earlier version of this patch that had a gt.wait() and didn't understand why it should be there; it looked to me as if it was making the operation synchronous, and thus there was no point in adding the overhead of another greenthread…"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-14 19:16:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

That's pretty much my point ;-)

Starting a thread to do something in parallel like waiting on the network manager is a good performance boost for a function, but to keep the same behavior outside of that scope you have to wait for the thread at the end.

I just don't think that not waiting (i.e having a deallocation and allocation going on at the same time for the same instance) could be guaranteed to be safe against system like Quantum

In the case of allocation (which I'm guessing inspired this change) there is other work to be getting on with, so its a good gain, but the calling thread does wait for the other one at the end.  
  
In the de-allocate case there really isn't anything much else to do, so you end up just starting the thread and then waiting for it.

So IMO the waits are needed, the question then is whether the additional complexity is really gaining anything ?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-22 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-22 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2013-06-22 19:14:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

I agree.  I don't think there's any benefit to this patch because there's really nothing to parallelize..   The build process is different... because there's image downloading and things like that."}]

commit_message:
Make _deallocate_network async

Deallocating IP addresses takes lot of time, especially if there are
more IPs, depending on the plugin being used. This change makes the
deallocation of network resources to happen in the separate thread

Change-Id: I26abaf06e9f9aa99fb9f784812383264271ab495

Before we add too much code that links us even more tightly to passing UserId/Password, we should try to abstract that away:  we need to be able to user Kerberos or Client Side Certificate verification for the initial authentication, and adding in password parameters to functions will make that harder, even if they are optional.  It might be as simple as renaming the password field to credential.  Take a look at how SASL tries to work around this:  we don't need anything quite that complicated, but it should give a sense of the problems we are going to face."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-06-05 15:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Take authorship for this! No need to maintain my name.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2013-06-05 23:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

adam- where exactly are we "adding code" to become more tightly bound to usernames / passwords? it's the default authentication method provided by openstack and it should receive first class support, but nothing here is introducing anything new in that respect, afaict'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2013-06-06 00:35:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2013-06-06 00:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-06 00:37:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

instantiating a client as follows:

  c = client.Client(
    token=c.auth_token,
    project_id='dc34d3f54a714bfab25cbf6ebd611899',
    auth_url=args.os_endpoint)
  c.authenticate()

resulted in the following scope being produced:

"scope": {"project": {"id": "dc34d3f54a714bfab25cbf6ebd611899", "name": "admin"}}

I'm honestly not sure where the project name came from (although it's accurate), but the 'name' attribute should NOT be included with the project 'id' in this case (as a bonus, keystone breaks as a result because it tries to lookup the project by name before it references the ID, which fails because no domain is specified).'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2013-06-21 06:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2013-06-21 06:36:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

Dolph: This patch fixes the issue you encountered.

In your code:

 c = client.Client(
    token=c.auth_token,
    project_id='dc34d3f54a714bfab25cbf6ebd611899',
    auth_url=args.os_endpoint)
#When the client is instantiated, it automatically authenticates with keystone. After authentication, it stores the project_name
  c.authenticate()
# At this point, both project_name and project_id is available in the client class. When building the "scope" for the token request, it automatically adds both. Fix the code to check if project_id is available, if available don't set the project_name anymore. Applied the same fix for user and domain as well.

Brant: Fixed the comments you had about backward compatibility.'}, {'account_id': 1941, 'date': '2013-06-21 06:38:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23:

Oops, the code review message didn't wrap automatically."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-21 07:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Works for me

Build succeeded.

commit_message:
Implements v3 auth client.

Added support for domain scoping.

Enhancement on AccessInfo to support reading v2/v3 token information.

Enhancement on ServiceCatalog for reading/filtering v2/v3 service
catalog information.

Change-Id: Ibb678b9933d3673e37d0fba857a152a3c5d2b4f4

[{'created': '2013-06-22 06:27:29.000000000', 'message': 'Fix IP spoofing filter blocking all packets.

Implement IP spoofing filter by adding yet another chain to iptables
with RETURN rule for each of IP addresses assigned to port and DROP
rule at the end of the chain.

Fixes: bug #1190613
Change-Id: I2e7a0f8dd4c3519c57d28e87a44735a3482624b1
(cherry picked from commit 531ff2fb34df9e6b0f84ada811c29240f0f1cd48)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix IP spoofing filter blocking all packets.

Implement IP spoofing filter by adding yet another chain to iptables
with RETURN rule for each of IP addresses assigned to port and DROP
rule at the end of the chain.

Fixes: bug #1190613
Change-Id: I2e7a0f8dd4c3519c57d28e87a44735a3482624b1
(cherry picked from commit 531ff2fb34df9e6b0f84ada811c29240f0f1cd48)

commit_message:
Fix sys_meta access in prep for instance object

Fix various places that access instance['system_metadata'] as if it's a
list of sqlalchemy models.  A helper util method was created in a
previous patch set in nova/utils... so this patch converts things to
use it.

Left one use in _init_instance() in compute/manager.py because it's
being addressed with a different patch set.

Related to blueprint unified-object-model

Change-Id: I876a6c57f64d61d64069c884bf0414c3596e1aa0

subject: Harmonize account and container GET/HEAD statues as per RFC 2616.
messages:
[{'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:19:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Does this have a documentation impact? It would seem the 1.0 documentation needs to be updated for account and containers. And will this possibly break any existing clients?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:56:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/2715 : SUCCESS in 1m 04s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-swift-docs/2545/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 05s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-swift-python26/2793 : SUCCESS in 2m 10s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-swift-python27/2791 : SUCCESS in 1m 18s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/22398 : FAILURE in 45m 28s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/29657 : FAILURE in 44m 30s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/22105 : FAILURE in 53m 43s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/9550 : SUCCESS in 15m 22s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-11 23:48:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Arguably, any client that breaks because of a change from one 2xx status code to another 2xx status code is simply wrong.

It's sort of like that that Java S3 client that some guy in #openstack-swift has to deal with that breaks if the (case-insensitive!) Etag header isn't capitalized as "ETag". At some point, you have to hold up the standard and tell clients to go fix themselves.

Also, having things be as they are on master may break any client expecting HTTP semantics.

I'll go take a look at the Swift docs and make sure they're not specifying particular response codes; that's definitely a good idea. I always forget about them since they're in some other repository somewhere, so "git grep" doesn't do me any good.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-11 23:48:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

...and it looks like Tempest is one of those broken clients. Great.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-11 23:50:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not merge

Note that the RFC uses the word SHOULD. Therefore, the current code is already correct with respect to RFC 2616. The reason HEAD and GET for accounts and containers were not originally implemented 100% exactly the same is due to the extra database overhead. This matters when you're doing several hundred of these HEADs per second across a cluster. It costs more cluster-wide and makes HEADs take longer for pretty much zero gain."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-12 00:00:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The "SHOULD" there only applies to the headers, not the status line (see section 6, "Response" for evidence that the status line is not a header). The status line has to match.

Alright, so what would you think of not doing DB queries to get Content-Length (for efficiency), but still making the status codes match up?'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-12 00:45:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Well, I'd say it's debatable whether the status code has to exactly match or if a 204 is okay in place of a 200.

If everybody goes with it MUST match exactly, then I don't see how you can do it in some cases without doing the GET work. For example, ?prefix=bob might 200 and might 204 depending on whether anything matches.

I'll change my score to -1 since I don't have any solid proof that 200/204 are similar enough to pass RFC 2616 HEAD requirements, but I don't much like this extra load for near-zero gain. We do a lot of HEAD requests just to check for existence. I guess we could add a new ?existence-check query parameter for that or something."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-12 00:52:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No, I'm on board with the efficiency argument. "It's really slow" is a darn good reason not to merge something. :)

I'll see if I can come up with a way to make status codes match that doesn't involve any extra DB accesses. I think it's possible. The headers won't match, because like you said, it's slow, but that's okay because the RFC says "SHOULD", not "MUST".'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-12 00:53:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Work In Progress

it's too slow to live"}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-12 23:43:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-12 23:47:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Alrighty, this patch is hopefully less terrible. :)

There's no additional DB accesses on a plain account or container HEAD. Only if you specify prefix/marker/end_marker/path do we go out and do the DB access, as that's the only way to tell if we should say 200 or 204.

Headers don't always match, but the status lines do.

As for the API documentation, I have a pending review over there to get rid of references to specific 2xx status codes, as (AFAIK) Swift has never really promised specific status codes, just "success". https://review.openstack.org/32769'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 00:40:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

Build failed.  For information on how to proceed, see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGithub#Test_Failures

- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-swift-pep8/2730 : SUCCESS in 40s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-swift-docs/2560/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 08s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-swift-python26/2808 : SUCCESS in 2m 07s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-swift-python27/2806 : SUCCESS in 1m 20s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-full/22779 : FAILURE in 57m 16s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/30077 : FAILURE in 17m 17s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/22486 : FAILURE in 40m 09s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32647/2/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/9894 : SUCCESS in 16m 37s (non-voting)
"}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-13 13:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yeah I'm okay with this approach. It'll probably break a few overly restrictive clients, which will make our Support folks hate us (more). Few other notes:

It seems a bit odd to have get_listing_params in account.utils.

At some point the new get_listing_params should get its own unit tests.

This whole "list of return values with possible error at end of list" pattern is getting weird to me. I mean, at some point we decided not to use HTTPException as an exception, but I'm not sure when or why anymore.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-13 17:41:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'll spend some time thinking about a new name for account.utils. Really, the only reason I didn't stick that stuff in common.utils is that I didn't want circular imports between swob and common.utils, but now we've got something in account/ that's used by the account, container, and proxy servers, so... yuck.

As for the raising of a Response subclass as an error... I guess that might work? I thought those all went away when we replaced webob, but it looks like there's code in swob to make all the various HTTPSomeStatus classes also be Exceptions. It'd certainly be less error-prone to raise HTTPBadRequest instead of returning it and relying on the caller to do the right thing.

Dunno. I chose a list of params+error mostly because I didn't think you could raise HTTPBadRequest and friends. I'll have to go poke at that and see if it works."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-13 18:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just things to consider for future work. No need to get them all figured out for this work. :)'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-14 16:58:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Work In Progress

gotta fix Tempest first

also, "statuses", not "statues". :)'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-22 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-22 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 22:02:13.000000000', 'message': 'Harmonize account and container GET/HEAD as per RFC 2616.

From RFC 2616, section 9.4 ("HEAD"):

    The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST
    NOT return a message-body in the response. The metainformation
    contained in the HTTP headers in response to a HEAD request SHOULD
    be identical to the information sent in response to a GET request.

This change makes account and container GET and HEAD requests correct
with respect to RFC 2616. Note that they were sometimes matched up
already, but they mismatched in many cases.

The changes are all to the HEAD responses; GET is unchanged.

Examples of mismatching requests:

$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when nonempty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=json
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=xml
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?delimiter=/
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?limit=two%20beers
$VERB /v1/account/container   (when empty)

Examples of matching requests:

$VERB /v1/account   (when empty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when drive not mounted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when deleted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=mp3

Bonus fix: the Content-Type for GET /v1/a/c was "text/html" for an
empty container and "text/plain" for a nonempty one; now it's always
"text/plain".

Change-Id: I5ab1eb85e777f259f4bd73a3a4a1802901925ed7
'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 23:43:06.000000000', 'message': 'Harmonize account and container GET/HEAD statues as per RFC 2616.

From RFC 2616, section 9.4 ("HEAD"):

    The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST
    NOT return a message-body in the response. The metainformation
    contained in the HTTP headers in response to a HEAD request SHOULD
    be identical to the information sent in response to a GET request.

This change makes account and container GET and HEAD responses have
the same status codes in all cases. This doesn't make the headers
always match because that would be too expensive (in terms of SQL
operations), but that's okay since header equality is only a
recommendation ("SHOULD").

The changes are all to the HEAD responses; GET is unchanged.

Examples of mismatching requests:

$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when nonempty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=json
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=xml
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?delimiter=/
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?limit=two%20beers
$VERB /v1/account/container   (when empty)

Examples of matching requests:

$VERB /v1/account   (when empty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when drive not mounted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when deleted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=mp3

Bonus fix: the Content-Type for GET /v1/a/c was "text/html" for an
empty container and "text/plain" for a nonempty one; now it's always
"text/plain".

Change-Id: I5ab1eb85e777f259f4bd73a3a4a1802901925ed7
'}]
commit_message:
Harmonize account and container GET/HEAD statues as per RFC 2616.

From RFC 2616, section 9.4 ("HEAD"):

    The HEAD method is identical to GET except that the server MUST
    NOT return a message-body in the response. The metainformation
    contained in the HTTP headers in response to a HEAD request SHOULD
    be identical to the information sent in response to a GET request.

This change makes account and container GET and HEAD responses have
the same status codes in all cases. This doesn't make the headers
always match because that would be too expensive (in terms of SQL
operations), but that's okay since header equality is only a
recommendation ("SHOULD").

The changes are all to the HEAD responses; GET is unchanged.

Examples of mismatching requests:

$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when nonempty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=json
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=xml
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?delimiter=/
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?limit=two%20beers
$VERB /v1/account/container   (when empty)

Examples of matching requests:

$VERB /v1/account   (when empty)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when drive not mounted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]   (when deleted)
$VERB /v1/account[/container]?format=mp3

Bonus fix: the Content-Type for GET /v1/a/c was "text/html" for an
empty container and "text/plain" for a nonempty one; now it's always
"text/plain".

Change-Id: I5ab1eb85e777f259f4bd73a3a4a1802901925ed7

[{'created': '2013-06-22 06:03:02.000000000', 'message': 'Start to add Quantum z/VM support

Quantum z/VM plugin and agent provide Quantum support for z/VM
virtual networks, following feature are supported for the initial
release:
1. VLAN support
2. DHCP support
z/VM agent are designed to support OVS plugin.

commit_message:
Start to add Quantum z/VM support.

This is the first commit to setup the framework and main work flow.
Quantum z/VM plugin and agent provide Quantum support for z/VM
virtual networks, for VLAN and FLAT mode. Quantum z/VM agent is
designed to support OVS plugin.

z/VM agent will use xCAT REST api to control and manage z/VM guest
systems and z/VM vswitch configuration.

Part of blueprint quantum-zvm-plugin

Change-Id: I4beff3036859a3828876b8da989bdd742fa15e58

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2013-06-13 12:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-15 11:03:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

2 things. I thought this was solved by disabling secure delete?

Secondly, we already support using an existing volume group named stack-volumes, which would let you use an underlying real partition. 

Both mean I'm not sure the complexity here is worth it."}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-06-17 11:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

@Sean: I experienced kernel lockups while the guest was writing to the volume, even with the noop scheduler, so the right solution is to skip the loopback device, and use a "real" hard drive. It was not resolved with disabling the secure delete. I ran the old style bfv tests (the one with a separate vm dd-ing bits to a volume), and I had the same lockup issues at that point.

So I had two options:
1. Prepare a stack-volumes before starting devstack (around patchset 11)
2. Modify devstack, so that it could create the stack-volumes group (latest patch)

The "problem" in the xenapi case, is that in order to create the volume group in the early phase of the installation, I had to explicitly install the lvm packages, and the whole solution looked a bit "ugly" (See patchset 11) It hard-coded the name "stack-volumes", and the whole thing was xenapi specific. This was option 1. Option 2, the latter patch makes it possible for other hypervisors to use the same approach, and eliminiated the need for installing lvm early, because at cinder time, the lvm subsystem is already installed.

There are other options as well
- if VOLUME_BACKING_FILE is a block device, skip loopback setup
- use a localrc setting: XEN_CREATE_XVDB, XEN_XVDB_SIZE - to create the XVDB

So on the client side, it would look like:

XEN_CREATE_XVDB=True
VOLUME_BACKING_FILE=/dev/xvdb

What do you think? What is the most complex part of the patch, that you want to see going away (kernel parameters maybe?). Give me some hints, so that I could come up with a better solution.

Mate'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-06-18 16:14:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

I have one additional use case here to consider:

* let stack.sh create stack-volumes on a set of disks (I've done this in the past in a pre-stack.sh script running devstack on bare metal via pxe; FWIW this is also why we don't remove the VG even if it is empty)

How about creating VOLUME_BACKING_DEVICE and if it is defined using it directly as $DEV and ignoring VOLUME_BACKING_FILE?  That would let me do the above as:

 VOLUME_BACKING_DEVICE="/dev/sdb /dev/sdc /dev/sdd"

and you would do:

 VOLUME_BACKING_DEVICE=/dev/xvdb

and the default remains to use a loopback device over VOLUME_BACKING_FILE.  I think that is simpler than trying to parse VOLUME_BACKING_FILE to test for block device or not.

Either way I'd support not using a kernel cmdline argument.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2013-06-18 16:21:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Argh, two more things...

* https://review.openstack.org/30227 is going to change the cleanup a bit, I don't think it will interfere functionally though but we need to verify

* this also needs to be handled for the CINDER_MULTI_LVM_BACKEND = True case (ie, VOLUME_GROUP2)."}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-06-19 09:01:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-06-19 09:01:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Work In Progress

Testing'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-06-19 09:15:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 5044, 'date': '2013-06-19 09:22:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-19 09:22:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

commit_message:
xenapi: separate disk for cinder volumes

Some kernels have lockup issues while serving cinder volumes from
file-loopback-lvm kind of cinder setup. This patch provides a way to
create an additional drive to the OpenStack VM, and use that to store
cinder volumes, thus eliminating the lockup issue. It will help when
testing XenServer. Now, you can specify devices for stack-volumes
through:

    VOLUME_BACKING_DEVICE

In case you are using CINDER_MULTI_LVM_BACKEND, you can use

    VOLUME_BACKING_DEVICE2

as well.

Xenserver:
Should you whish to use a 10 gig disk backend for your cinder volumes,
specify:

    XEN_XVDB_SIZE_GB=10
    VOLUME_BACKING_DEVICE=/dev/xvdb

Citrix is using this approach on its internal CI system to run tests
against OpenStack. This is a workaround for this bug:

  https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1023755

Related to blueprint xenapi-devstack-cleanup

[{'created': '2013-05-16 02:41:18.000000000', 'message': 'Base.get_engine honor allow_global_engine=False

This change makes it so that get_engine() in
keystone.common.sql.core.Base does not return the global engine
when allow_global_engine is False.

Change-Id: I756b54d9f3984733f56d09c11b2702c3451102f2
'}, {'created': '2013-05-18 15:03:26.000000000', 'message': 'Base.get_engine honor allow_global_engine=False

This change makes it so that get_engine() in
keystone.common.sql.core.Base does not return the global engine
when allow_global_engine is False.

The behavior before could be described like:
If get_engine() has never been called with allow_global_engine=True,
then if you pass allow_global_engine=False returns a new engine.
Otherwise, you always get the global engine.

The new behavior can be described like:
If get_engine() is called with allow_global_engine=True then
it returns the global engine, otherwise it returns a new engine.

Change-Id: I756b54d9f3984733f56d09c11b2702c3451102f2
'}, {'created': '2013-05-18 18:32:55.000000000', 'message': 'Base.get_engine honor allow_global_engine=False

then if you pass allow_global_engine=False returns a new engine.
Otherwise, you always get the global engine (even if
allow_global_engine=False)

The new behavior is:
If get_engine() is called with allow_global_engine=True then
it returns the global engine, otherwise it returns a new engine.

Change-Id: I756b54d9f3984733f56d09c11b2702c3451102f2

commit_message:
Base.get_engine honor allow_global_engine=False

This change makes it so that get_engine() in
keystone.common.sql.core.Base does not return the global engine
when allow_global_engine is False.

The behavior before could be described like:
If get_engine() has never been called with allow_global_engine=True,
then if you pass allow_global_engine=False returns a new engine.
Otherwise, you always get the global engine (even if
allow_global_engine=False)

The new behavior is:
If get_engine() is called with allow_global_engine=True then
it returns the global engine, otherwise it returns a new engine.

Change-Id: I756b54d9f3984733f56d09c11b2702c3451102f2

commit_message:
Fix test_volumes_get volumes cleanup.

Currently for test_volumes_get if the volume creation fails and we won't define
the volume variable which will result in an undefined error in the finally
block that always gets run. This will mask the actual cause of the test
failure. This commit fixes this by reworking the cleanup logic in the tests
to use the addCleanup so if the api call fails the actual error will be printed.

Change-Id: I2619575fe80d4f3ce38cc951e7dbd44311d61432

commit_message:
Add a volume create/delete stress test

Simply performs a create/delete operation, in a while loop for the
duration passed to run_stress.py

Change-Id: I006f3754f1fc1cabfbb90ed72704b2185dcc4e5f
Fixes: bug #1192227

commit_message:
Port missing bits from httplib2 to requests

This allows to drop the dependency on httplib2 altogether.

Change-Id: I18571e29d9f0d6527a93ed18becee9148e64e574

commit_message:
Implement Browser session timeout

By default, Horizon just uses session, which expire, when the browser
is closed. This implements additionally a session timeout.

Change-Id: I140ee2ee37e092036a66d890d920423dfc493fba
Fixes: bug 1118441

My understanding is that when we add new DB tables we need to ensure that there is a migration. For example there may be people who are using code that is in master and if they get the new code then starting a service may cause problems due to the fact that there is no migration.
I am fine with adding this code if you open a bug for the migration script so that we can track it.
Thanks

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 22:34:47.000000000', 'message': 'Adds support for router rules to Big Switch plugin

Implements: blueprint bsn-router-rules

Adds bigswitch plugin extension which adds 'rules' dictionary to router objects.
Adds validation code and database components to store router rules
Adds configuration option to plugin to set default router rules and max router rules
Adds unit tests to test all router rule functionality
Adds database migration for router rules tables

The Big Switch controller's Virtual Router implementation supports "routing rules"
which are of the form:
<source, destination, next-hop, action>
This extension aims to expose this abstraction via the Big Switch Quantum plugin.

These rules are applied at the router level, allowing tenants to control
communication between networks at a high level without requiring security policies.
(e.g. prevent servers in a publicly accessible subnet from communicating with
database servers).

Change-Id: I37a2740dca93b0a8b5111764458d39f1c2b885ce

commit_message:
Adds support for router rules to Big Switch plugin

Implements: blueprint bsn-router-rules

Adds bigswitch plugin extension which adds 'rules' dictionary to router objects.
Adds validation code and database components to store router rules
Adds configuration option to plugin to set default router rules and max router rules
Adds unit tests to test all router rule functionality
Adds database migration for router rules tables

The Big Switch controller's Virtual Router implementation supports "routing rules"
which are of the form:
<source, destination, next-hop, action>
This extension aims to expose this abstraction via the Big Switch Quantum plugin.

These rules are applied at the router level, allowing tenants to control
communication between networks at a high level without requiring security policies.
(e.g. prevent servers in a publicly accessible subnet from communicating with
database servers).

Change-Id: I37a2740dca93b0a8b5111764458d39f1c2b885ce

commit_message:
Ignore import lines with noqa

flake8 says that lines with '# noqa' should be ignored, but the
import rules checker isn't ignoring those lines.

This change makes it so that import lines with # noqa are ignored.

Change-Id: Icb2c3eaf0cec87e18bc3c6dcf28f8e2642ec23a2
Fixes: bug 1186188

commit_message:
Adds create_from_volume test cases

  For tests.test_volumes,
  added 3 test cases:
     create_from_volume
     create_from_volume_with_glance_metadata
     create_from_volume_failed_on_cloning
  refactored an internal api:
     _create_volume_from_image

  The reason not to test a non-exist volume as source_vol is
  the uplayer(volume api) has already checked and ensured the
  source_vol exists
Change-Id: I6158a60fe0b578f3c110bb05ec1be9bb93349ce3

[{'created': '2013-06-20 00:33:57.000000000', 'message': 'Always restart devstack-gate when testing itself.

Devstack-gate was only restarting itself when the ZUUL_PROJECT was
devstack-gate. In the zuul gate queue projects are stacked and
ZUUL_PROJECT may be some other project when ZUUL_CHANGES includes a
change to devstack-gate. Restart devstack-gate whenever it is part of
ZUUL_CHANGES.

Change-Id: I1c34917bf2b1dbc732eb1d36c3b7c30a1d8822bd
'}]
commit_message:
Always restart devstack-gate when testing itself.

Devstack-gate was only restarting itself when the ZUUL_PROJECT was
devstack-gate. In the zuul gate queue projects are stacked and
ZUUL_PROJECT may be some other project when ZUUL_CHANGES includes a
change to devstack-gate. Restart devstack-gate whenever it is part of
ZUUL_CHANGES.

Change-Id: I1c34917bf2b1dbc732eb1d36c3b7c30a1d8822bd

commit_message:
Added cinder volumes support to vanilla plugin

* Added [/mnt] storage by default in NG model
* Added Hadoop data dirs configuration for multiple storages

Change-Id: Iaafbef5a5d7a6be3f121cfe5c9e17f4718416aec

Change-Id: I4a7436b8d928e3fb18a07ec8234253c32cb3b6d9
'}]
commit_message:
Compute Admin image guide refactor

Removed old content about creating custom images from the Compute
Admin Guide, added a pointer to the image guide.

Moved section about capturing images from runningi nstances from
the Compute Admin Guide to the CLI guide.

Rebase against master to try to merge.

Change-Id: I4a7436b8d928e3fb18a07ec8234253c32cb3b6d9

Fix KeyError exception when scheduling to child cell.

Fix typo 'security_group' and update related unit tests.

Fix bug #1193233

When exceptions committing or rolling back quota reservations occurs, we
log the failure.  However, the code also falls through to log a

commit_message:
Fix quota logging on exceptions

When exceptions committing or rolling back quota reservations occurs, we
log the failure.  However, the code also falls through to log a
succesful commit/rollback.  This adds the missing returns.

Change-Id: Ieccb4071c64dde740ec95a783533a8a3a1850481

commit_message:
Refactor the backup method of SwiftBackupService

Export functionalities of backup to 3 new methods:
prepare_backup backup_chunk and finalize_backup. The original
backup function calls those functions. This allows other
drivers to combine them in a different logic.
e.g for the RBDDriver

Change-Id: I4f335bfcd03cd1da52a9e5c5c689d97581614af6

'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-12 14:04:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

one thing I know will come up - why am I returning the transaction ID with put_object() and the response headers with delete_object()?

the simple answer is because get_object() returns the headers and that would have been my preference everywhere, but put_object() already returns the etag so I just added the transaction ID.  I did think about returning the whole set of headers but it sort of felt redundant, but I can certainly do that if it's what people prefer."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-12 23:13:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

When thinking about how to change the API to return this stuff, I wanted it backwards compatible (i.e. not forcing existing callers of put_object to expect a tuple to be returned).

I was leaning toward a new, optional kwarg to all the functions which don't already return response headers (post_account, put_container, post_container, delete_container, put_object, post_object, and delete_object).  If specified, that kwarg's value would be a dict which would be updated with the response headers, with lower-cased keys like get_object does.

So usage would be something like this:

  resp_headers = {}
  etag = conn.put_object(..., resp_headers=resp_headers)
  the_tx_id = resp_headers['i-irans-id']

Note that the Connection class's helper functions would need that optional kwarg plumbed through to the calls to self._retry().

The inlined client.py that ssbench uses also tracks time-to-first-byte for GETs and overall request latencies (time to last byte) and returns those as additional headers prefixed with "x-...".  That's another reason I'd like all headers to (be able to) come out of these function calls vs. just returning the transaction ID.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-06-13 07:57:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I agree with Darrell even tho it's a bit bigger change to this review it would be something good to do this properly."}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-13 14:42:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This does sound reasonable and I can certainly change my direction but a question first:

It sounds like the suggestion to only add this functionality to those functions not already returning headers.  It would seem to me that for consistency I'd rather add it everywhere.  That would mean that get_object could then have the ability to return headers 2 ways.  However I don't have any feel for the extra overhead involved in doing so, but if not a lot, why not just do it?

I would then suggest we deprecate the current way header information is returned by both put/get and maybe some years in the futures actually drop it, if at all."}, {'account_id': 917, 'date': '2013-06-13 15:02:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hah... I had just started on a similar change, but I have a ton on my plate, so I'm more than happy to let you run with it.

The approach I was taking was:

1.  Add a verbose kwarg to each function call that would default to false.
2.  If verbose=True, then return a tuple with the normal return value, and a dictionary of the verbose data.

The verbose data would be a dictionary with the following info:

* response # response code
* reason # reason for response code
* headers # dictionary of headers

This is a bit of a compromise in not breaking current clients, but allowing people to add it if needed with minor code changes.  Let me know what you think, and if you would like to keep running with it."}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-13 15:55:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So just to be clear you and darrell suggested different approaches.  You're suggested an even broader set of data being returned and I'm fine with that and so think that's what I'll do."}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-13 17:22:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

digging deeper, I found get_account, get_container, head_object, head_container and head_account all already return response headers, but I think I'd still like to return than consistently in get as with put, delete, post, etc.

In any event, once I post my code we can talk it all through."}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-13 18:12:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 18:26:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-13 18:43:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

so I sort of blended Darrell and Chuck's suggestions with a little sauce of my own.

I added an optional parameter called 'response' that is an dictionary.

I then added that to all the functions Darrell recommended plus get, because it doesn't feel right to make that one the odd man out of the big 3 (in my opinion) of put, get and delete.  I left the other which already returns headers alone but we might also want to think about doing more with them too.

Response returns a dictionary of 3 items, the first 2 being the status of the operation and the reason, named 'status' and 'reason'.  The 3rd is a dictionary of headers called 'headers'.

The one thing I hadn't done yet is test all the functions as I don't have any test scripts at my finger tips and was hoping someone else might already.  I looked at the existing tests and they don't look like they do anything with optional parameters.

I'm reasonably confident this will work everywhere as I did test it with get, put, delete and put_container.  However all the modified functions really do need to be tested and I can certainly do that if nobody else can."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-14 23:23:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If so, could it be added on subsequent patch, or should it get done on this one?"}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-19 21:35:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Quite honestly I'm not really up on the subtleties/implications/interactions of my changes with the retry mechanisms and perhaps someone closer to that code could/should comment.  Might it be ok to let these changes move forward as in and that someone deal with the retry logic to make sure it is done correctly?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-19 23:33:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

The (untested) code snippet below would result in the caller's response_dict getting all the normal values of the last retry, as well as a "response_dicts" key which is a list of the response dict for every (sub)request.  A count of tries is available to the caller as len(response_dict['response_dicts']).  The count of retries would be one less than that.

      def _add_response_dict(self, target_dict, response_dict):
          if target_dict is not None:
              if 'response_dicts' in target_dict:
                  target_dict['response_dicts'].append(response_dict)
              else:
                  target_dict['response_dicts'] = [response_dict]
              target_dict.update(response_dict)
  
      def _retry(self, reset_func, func, *args, **kwargs):
          self.attempts = 0
          backoff = self.starting_backoff
          caller_response_dict = kwargs.pop('response_dict', None)
          while self.attempts <= self.retries:
              self.attempts += 1
              try:
                  ...
                  kwargs['http_conn'] = self.http_conn
                  keargs['response_dict'] = {}
                  rv = func(self.url, self.token, *args, **kwargs)
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict,
                                          kwargs['response_dict'])
                  return rv
              except (socket.error, HTTPException):
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict,
                                          kwargs['response_dict'])
                  ...
              except ClientException as err:
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict,
                                          kwargs['response_dict'])
                  ...'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-19 23:47:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Rats!  I had a typo on a line which needed to be conditional anyway.  The assignment of an empty dict into kwargs['response_dict'] should not happen if the original call didn't have it.  Otherwise you'll get a crash from the API methods which don't *have* a response_dict in their method signature.

  ...
  if caller_response_dict:
      kwargs['response_dict'] = {}
  rv = func(self.url, self.token, *args, **kwargs)
  ..."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-19 23:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

LOL, I should have tried to run it.  This seems to actually work:

      def _add_response_dict(self, target_dict, kwargs):
          if target_dict is not None:
              response_dict = kwargs['response_dict']
              if 'response_dicts' in target_dict:
                  target_dict['response_dicts'].append(response_dict)
              else:
                  target_dict['response_dicts'] = [response_dict]
              target_dict.update(response_dict)
  
      def _retry(self, reset_func, func, *args, **kwargs):
          self.attempts = 0
          backoff = self.starting_backoff
          caller_response_dict = kwargs.pop('response_dict', None)
          while self.attempts <= self.retries:
              self.attempts += 1
              try:
                  if not self.url or not self.token:
                      self.url, self.token = self.get_auth()
                      self.http_conn = None
                  if not self.http_conn:
                      self.http_conn = self.http_connection()
                  kwargs['http_conn'] = self.http_conn
                  if caller_response_dict:
                      kwargs['response_dict'] = {}
                  rv = func(self.url, self.token, *args, **kwargs)
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict, kwargs)
                  return rv
              except (socket.error, HTTPException):
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict, kwargs)
                  if self.attempts > self.retries:
                      raise
                  self.http_conn = None
              except ClientException as err:
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict, kwargs)"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2013-06-20 00:25:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Sorry for the continued spam, but I actually *exercised* it and found another bug.  This does what I intended:

      def _add_response_dict(self, target_dict, kwargs):                                              
          if target_dict is not None:                                                                 
              response_dict = kwargs['response_dict']                                                 
              if 'response_dicts' in target_dict:
                  target_dict['response_dicts'].append(response_dict)                                 
              else:
                  target_dict['response_dicts'] = [response_dict]                                     
              target_dict.update(response_dict)                                                       
                
      def _retry(self, reset_func, func, *args, **kwargs):                                            
          self.attempts = 0
          backoff = self.starting_backoff                                                             
          caller_response_dict = kwargs.pop('response_dict', None)                                    
          while self.attempts <= self.retries:                                                        
              self.attempts += 1                                                                      
              try: 
                  if not self.url or not self.token:
                      self.url, self.token = self.get_auth()
                      self.http_conn = None
                  if not self.http_conn:                                                              
                      self.http_conn = self.http_connection()                                         
                  kwargs['http_conn'] = self.http_conn
                  if caller_response_dict is not None: 
                      kwargs['response_dict'] = {}                                                    
                  rv = func(self.url, self.token, *args, **kwargs)                                    
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict, kwargs)                               
                  return rv
              except (socket.error, HTTPException):                                                   
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict, kwargs)                               
                  if self.attempts > self.retries:                                                    
                      raise 
                  self.http_conn = None                                                               
              except ClientException as err:                                                          
                  self._add_response_dict(caller_response_dict, kwargs)
  ..."}, {'account_id': 7661, 'date': '2013-06-20 11:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-20 11:52:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

commit_message:
add optional 'response_dict' parameters to many calls into which they'll
return a dictionary of the response status, reason and headers

Change-Id: I35f8824537f0484362dd6646c91789fac02fa075

commit_message:
WIP Shelve an instance

This is a basic outline of how shelving will work.  Unshelving isn't in
place yet.

The basic idea is that an instance can be put into a shelved state which
snapshots it, unless volume backed, and powers it down.  A periodic task
on the compute nodes will clean up the instance after a configurable
period of time(default: 3 days).  This should allow for fast startup
times when an instance is shelved for a night or over a weekend, and
free up resources when left longer.

This will end up broken into smaller patchsets.

part of blueprint shelve-instance

Change-Id: Iae0c8f8cb1e4e33aaed3f2f58b57f84b168eedae

commit_message:
Include HACKING.rst in MANIFEST.in

Without this, I'm seeing:

  Running setup.py egg_info for package from file:///.../hacking-0.5.5.6.ga6bef44.zip
    error in setup command: Error parsing ../setup.cfg: IOError: 2

This is a "file not found" when it tries to open HACKING.rst.

Not sure whether something changed recently to cause this to start
happening.

Change-Id: I499332181c83a7bb127261efd6354ae4d92f5709

commit_message:
Clarified some steps of the installation process

Fixes bug 1192630

Changed the title of the instruction regarding the user creation, as
users with other names run into bugs.
Changed the bash $ symbol for some commands to # where commands are
ran as a root user
Corrected syntax for NOPASSWD in sudoers
Added ip tables rule to allow guest access to the internet

Change-Id: Iffa402fa2d717b53dab01bbefcc10943d05d6169

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-20 22:44:07.000000000', 'message': "Do not refresh timestamp from database on read.

Doing a database refresh on timestamp read is causing errors
such as:
heat.openstack.common.rpc.amqp InvalidRequestError:
  Could not refresh instance '<Stack at 0x2c95a90>'

This has only been seen using postgres, possibly because the problem is
being masked on mysql due to the driver's lack of concurrency.

The database refresh seems to be unnecessary, as there appears to be
no logic which depends on timestamps being accurate (nor is there
any timestamp comparison logic at all)

Fixes bug: #1193132
Change-Id: I22c3c4546a0f44b76a95e473b68b6fbb2e423b90
"}]
commit_message:
Do not refresh timestamp from database on read.

Doing a database refresh on timestamp read is causing errors
such as:
heat.openstack.common.rpc.amqp InvalidRequestError:
  Could not refresh instance '<Stack at 0x2c95a90>'

This has only been seen using postgres, possibly because the problem is
being masked on mysql due to the driver's lack of concurrency.

The database refresh seems to be unnecessary, as there appears to be
no logic which depends on timestamps being accurate (nor is there
any timestamp comparison logic at all)

Fixes bug: #1193132
Change-Id: I22c3c4546a0f44b76a95e473b68b6fbb2e423b90

commit_message:
Add Chassis DB model and DB-API.

This patch adds a 'extra', 'updated_at' and 'created_at'
attributes to the DB model of a chassis and DB-API methods
for CRUD operations on chassis.

Implements blueprint: ironic-object-model

Change-Id: I9240f318ad34752f93c1f16607b6d46658881dc4

[{'created': '2013-06-21 15:38:12.000000000', 'message': 'Includes tenant_id when removing floating IPs from the backend controller

Quantum does not include the tenant_id in port objects for floating IP addresses.
However, the Big Switch backend requires the tenant_id in the port removal requests.
This looks up the correct tenant_id whenever it is missing in the port removal.

Change-Id: I7580ed2f545ad2d92b831b65dfbb34541bf465aa
Fixes: bug #1190020
'}, {'created': '2013-06-21 15:38:12.000000000', 'message': 'Always include tenant_id in port delete request

Quantum does not include the tenant_id in port objects for floating IP addresses.
However, the Big Switch backend requires the tenant_id in the port removal requests.
This looks up the correct tenant_id whenever it is missing in the port removal.

Change-Id: I7580ed2f545ad2d92b831b65dfbb34541bf465aa
Fixes: bug #1190020
'}]
commit_message:
Always include tenant_id in port delete request

Quantum does not include the tenant_id in port objects for floating IP addresses.
However, the Big Switch backend requires the tenant_id in the port removal requests.
This looks up the correct tenant_id whenever it is missing in the port removal.

Change-Id: I7580ed2f545ad2d92b831b65dfbb34541bf465aa
Fixes: bug #1190020

commit_message:
Set default volume backing file size to 10G

This commit changes the default volume backing file size from 5G to
10G. This is already done in devstack-gate because on tempest runs
we would frequently go above 5G. This will mirror the change for all
devstack runs not just in the gate.

Change-Id: I7023237653a28a4bb9413540ad9ecf3dfa588b0a

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-08 20:14:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This doesn't remove any Glance dependency. The tests for multiple images and flavors is done over the compute API, not the Glance API.

I'm skeptical of whether this patch actually reduces runtime significantly."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-08 20:47:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Jay: Try this 

nosetests --collect-only 2>&1 | sed 's/\([^ \[]*\)[ \[].*/\1/' | grep ^tempest| sed 's/\(.*\)[.]\(.*[.].*\)/\1:\2/' | xargs -n 1 nosetests 2>&1 | tee ../results # the dumb way

This one of the main reason why an individual test case start slow.

Now this code part runs whenever the class loaded."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-08 22:00:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, but there still isn't a Glance dependency, like the commit message says...

Also, in the commit message you say "Adding the flavor extra configuration option to the configuration file until we cannot move to attribute based test selection."

Could you elaborate on that? I am not sure what you mean.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-09 04:22:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

atttr() decorator can be used for skip decisions.
We can select test cases by that without populating, the config file, and adding additional logic for every case.

In different environment you can have more reasons for skipping test cases.

- you just want to run test cases which effects combination of services
- your backend (hyper-visor or volume)  does not supports a certain operation.
- you do not have admin privileges.
- you just need the test cases which related to a single component. (with and without additional integration (network+compute, volume+compute))'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-09 04:28:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2013-06-09 04:28:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

[{'created': '2013-06-08 07:40:59.000000000', 'message': 'Remove glance dependency for every test case

* Frequent complain against tempest it needs more services for a
test than it is necessary.

* The automated skip decisions are expensive, it is visible
  if you just run a single test case.

* The automated skip decisions are not fully trusted, so we should avoid them.

* Adding the flavor extra configuration option to the configuration file
 until we cannot move to attribute based test selection.

* Adding the CLI section to the tempest.conf.sample

Change-Id: I81a408392a8de38b694b3132572b6e48700595a3

commit_message:
Remove automated skip decsion from compute

* The automated skip decisions are expensive, it is visible
  if you just run a single test case.

* The automated skip decisions are not fully trusted, so we should avoid them.

* Adding the flavor extra configuration option to the configuration file
 until we cannot move to test case attribute based test selection.

* Adding the CLI section to the tempest.conf.sample

Change-Id: I81a408392a8de38b694b3132572b6e48700595a3

commit_message:
Added utils.FileLikeIter

A really simple version of this was in container sync already, and I
needed a more complete version for work I'm doing, and I noticed
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33405/ was also making use of it.
So, here's a more full version.

If https://review.openstack.org/#/c/33405/ lands before this, I'll
update it accordingly.

Change-Id: Iba66b6a97f65e312e04fdba273e8f4ad1d3e1594

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-20 01:42:16.000000000', 'message': "Actually raise BadRequest if create_subnet fails

Second attempt at fixing a problem in the Tempest
network test base setup where it tries to create
a subnet and if it fails it needs to raise a
BadRequest rather than an UnboundLocalError from
trying to use the body variable before it's declared.

Fixes bug 1192767

Change-Id: I2c97723b1056ae34e68a5acb5283c291a5dcfad1
"}]
commit_message:
Actually raise BadRequest if create_subnet fails

Second attempt at fixing a problem in the Tempest
network test base setup where it tries to create
a subnet and if it fails it needs to raise a
BadRequest rather than an UnboundLocalError from
trying to use the body variable before it's declared.

Fixes bug 1192767

Change-Id: I2c97723b1056ae34e68a5acb5283c291a5dcfad1

[{'created': '2013-03-11 17:36:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add "normal", optparse-style options to swift-ring-builder add.

The old format is still present and works just like it did before, so
your existing scripts won't break.

New format pros:
 * it's readable even for Swift newcomers
 * it's easy to extend
 * it's familiar to anyone who's used a Unix command line
 * we don't have to maintain the parser

New format cons:
 * you can't add multiple devices in one go

Old format pros:
 * you can add many devices with one command
 * it's compact

Old format cons:
 * it confuses newcomers
 * "wait, is that zone dash IP colon port slash device, or zone slash
   IP dash port colon meta underscore device?" Just try walking
   someone through adding a device in person or over voice chat. I
   double-dog dare you.
 * it's annoying to add new fields

Note that this only affects the command "swift-ring-builder
<builderfile> add". Other swift-ring-builder commands are unchanged.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I034b7f79eb6f4d81a5c4da193e1358741441c5b5

commit_message:
Add "normal", optparse-style options to swift-ring-builder add.

The old format is still present and works just like it did before, so
your existing scripts won't break.

New format pros:
 * it's readable even for Swift newcomers
 * it's easy to extend
 * it's familiar to anyone who's used a Unix command line
 * we don't have to maintain the parser

New format cons:
 * you can't add multiple devices in one go

Old format pros:
 * you can add many devices with one command
 * it's compact

Old format cons:
 * it confuses newcomers
 * "wait, is that zone dash IP colon port slash device, or zone slash
   IP dash port colon meta underscore device?" Just try walking
   someone through adding a device over voice chat.
 * it's annoying to add new fields

Note that this only affects the command "swift-ring-builder
<builderfile> add". Other swift-ring-builder commands are unchanged.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I034b7f79eb6f4d81a5c4da193e1358741441c5b5

commit_message:
Fix create_security_group_rule to work with python 2.6

Change 59f00281ef1fa9448f5caf78a1c558625c83f65e introduced new code
which only works on python 2.7. This patch keeps the same function as
that change but makes it also work on python 2.6.

Fixes bug 1193066

Change-Id: I701259020f1ff15c0082328895ddc32cec9d3da1

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-21 15:22:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix mocking of HTTPClient.request() method.

The test_extend_list_exceed_max_uri_len test case mocks
the request() method of HTTPClient class so that it raises
the RequestURITooLong exception. But the real method can't
possibly raise it (Client.do_request() does this instead).
Mocks should emulate the behavior of methods they stub out
and not change it in any way.

Fixes bug 1192197.

Change-Id: I62b2db111ef251f95eb9aa9c9cc00b53fdbccc68
"}]
commit_message:
Fix mocking of HTTPClient.request() method.

The test_extend_list_exceed_max_uri_len test case mocks
the request() method of HTTPClient class so that it raises
the RequestURITooLong exception. But the real method can't
possibly raise it (Client.do_request() does this instead).
Mocks should emulate the behavior of methods they stub out
and not change it in any way.

Fixes bug 1192197.

Change-Id: I62b2db111ef251f95eb9aa9c9cc00b53fdbccc68

commit_message:
Make --version option print a more detailed client version.

The python quantum client was printing "quantum 2.0" regardless of
the version of the client.  This seems to be the version of the
API but people expect the version of the client to be printed.

I looked at the implementation of --version in nova and keystone.
The one in keystone worked and was fairly straight-forward
utilizing code from the pbr package.  I added this code to version.py
rather than __init__.py.

Change-Id: I53264b454eb16d5c294ad40ab6494387637950db
Fixes: Bug #1190652

commit_message:
Fix haproxy plugin_driver.update_health_monitor() signature

- add old_health_monitor parameter to the method
- the method signature in abstract lbaas driver was also changed
  to accept pool_id rather than an assoc object as driver only needs pool_id

Fixes bug 1190577

[{'created': '2013-06-20 18:50:47.000000000', 'message': 'Upgrade glance policy for grenade

Some tempest failures were caused by a lack of one rule
in the policy.json file for glance. Get the policy file
from the latest release to the configuration file to ensure
all rules are considered.

Fix bug 1189631

Change-Id: I2479252434ce7a8bd17da86bef558e9a68579b2f
'}]
commit_message:
Upgrade glance policy for grenade

Some tempest failures were caused by a lack of one rule
in the policy.json file for glance. Get the policy file
from the latest release to the configuration file to ensure
all rules are considered.

Fix bug 1189631

Change-Id: I2479252434ce7a8bd17da86bef558e9a68579b2f
